The main aspects encompass the prediction of elements’ behavior in the structure, the formal evaluation from sophisticated characterization techniques, industrial scalability of low-cost catalysts for reforming processes, and durability. Table 1 Comparison between conventional catalysts and high-entropy materials for reforming reactions. Criterion Conventional catalysts High-entropy materials (HEMs) Thermodynamic stability Thermodynamically stable only at low temperatures or specific stoichiometries. Entropy-stabilized phases are thermodynamically favored at high T due to high configurational entropy (ΔS mix > 1.5R), even with ΔH mix > 0 [22,23]. Phase formation/single phase Phase separation often occurs when mixing elements with large ionic radius differences. High entropy promotes single-phase formation even with dissimilar cations, enabling homogeneous active sites and new catalytic pathways [3,25–27]. Coking resistance Susceptible to coke formation during reforming, especially on Ni-based catalysts. Increased oxygen vacancies and the M−O bond activation reduce coking by promoting oxidation of carbon deposits [28,34]. Structural stability (sintering) High metal mobility under reforming conditions leads to particle growth and deactivation. High lattice distortion and reduced melting point promote dynamic metal exsolution and re-incorporation, maintaining active sites [28]. Defect engineering/vacancies Limited capacity for controlled defect generation. Up to 10× increase in cationic or oxygen vacancy concentration, enhancing ionic conductivity and catalytic activity [33,34]. Compositional flexibility Restricted to a few binary/ternary systems. Capable of incorporating 5 elements from different groups (transition, rare-earth, and alkali), unlocking new synergistic effects [3,25–27]. Electronic structure tuning Rigid energy levels dictated by one or two metals. Orbital distortion and cocktail effects allow tuning of activation barriers and multi-electron reactions [41–44]. Anion/cation disorder Typically limited to cation substitution in simple lattices. Capable of dual-site engineering (A/B in perovskites, Td/Oh in spinels), and even multianionic systems (e.g., F−, O2−, S2−) with enhanced ion mobility [38–40]. Catalyst deactivation (S poisoning) Active sites poisoned by sulfur and other impurities. Multielement synergy and diluted active sites can suppress poisoning and enhance tolerance [44]. Scalability and design Dependent on noble metals or scarce precursors. Enables discovery of catalysts without Pt, Rh, Pd, etc., supported by artificial intelligence and high-throughput exploration [45]. Table 2 Contaminants and their impacts. Particulate matter Clogging in compressors, storage tanks, and engines due to buildup. H2S Corrosion of compressors, storage tanks, and engines; toxic concentrations (>5 cm3 m−3) present in biogas; formation of SO2 and SO3 during combustion, which in the presence of water form highly toxic and corrosive acids. CO2 Low calorific power Siloxanes Formation of silica and quartz microcrystals during combustion; deposition on sparking plugs, cylinders, and valves. Graphic abstract This review consolidates recent insights into entropy-driven catalytic design, mapping synthesis, structure, and performance relationships to guide next-generation hydrogen production technologies. Hydrogen production via catalytic reforming of renewable fuels represents a pivotal strategy in the decarbonization of energy systems. However, conventional catalysts continue to encounter persistent challenges, including sintering, carbon deposition, and structural degradation under severe reaction conditions. This review addresses the growing need to consolidate the rapidly expanding body of knowledge on medium- and high-entropy materials (MEMs and HEMs), whose unique thermodynamic features position them as next-generation catalysts with the potential to overcome these limitations. The discussion is organized to examine how entropy stabilization, lattice distortion, and multi-elemental synergy influence catalytic behavior. Materials are categorized by crystal structure (e.g., perovskite, spinel, and periclase) and by their roles in key reforming processes, including steam, dry, partial oxidation, and autothermal reforming of renewable fuels such as bioethanol, biomethane, and methanol. A detailed comparison of synthesis methods, configurational entropy thresholds, and physicochemical characteristics is presented. The review synthesizes key insights from recent studies, including advances in exsolution-driven nanostructuring, the impact of oxygen vacancy engineering, and the performance of entropy-optimized compositions under practical reforming conditions. It offers a comprehensive mapping of structure-performance relationships, underscoring how entropy can be harnessed to design more robust, selective, and efficient catalytic systems. Future perspectives emphasize the exploration of underinvestigated entropy-stabilized systems (e.g., nitrides and sulfides), the integration of data-driven design approaches, and the imperative for long-term stability evaluations under industrially relevant conditions. Finally, the review highlights promising opportunities for scaling up entropy-based catalysts and aligning their development with techno-economic and environmental benchmarks. This work aims to serve as both a comprehensive reference and a strategic outlook for advancing hydrogen production technologies through entropy-engineered catalysis. Keywords High-entropy materials Medium-entropy materials Hydrogen production Fuel reforming Catalysts Entropy stabilization Energy transition 1 Introduction The rapidly growing global energy demand, coupled with the increasing complexity of environmental challenges, represents one of the most pressing concerns of the 21st century. Intensifying global warming and the resulting climate crisis have catalyzed a global shift toward the development of emission-free alternative energy sources [1]. A promising approach to reducing reliance on conventional feedstocks involves the use of hydrogen as an energy carrier, offering the advantage of near-zero carbon emissions and a significant reduction in atmospheric pollutants [2]. In fact, H2 boasts an energy density of 143 MJ/kg, which surpasses that of any liquid hydrocarbon-based fuel threefold [1]. However, hydrogen’s low volumetric energy density in its gaseous form necessitates compression to extremely high pressures (up to ∼1000 bar) for efficient transport and utilization—an obstacle that has limited its practicality as a fuel for over a century, despite its commercial production via natural gas reforming. In this context, producing hydrogen from renewable energy sources, particularly through easily transportable biofuels, has emerged as a promising alternative to address both environmental and logistical challenges. Strategic reforming of renewable fuels thus plays a pivotal role in advancing green chemistry and clean energy technologies. Hydrogen production from catalytic reforming of renewable fuels can be achieved through various routes using different oxidants. The most common processes include steam reforming (H2O), dry reforming (CO2), and partial oxidation (O2) over a catalyst often based on nickel, ruthenium, or rhodium. In steam reforming, the fuel reacts with steam (H2O) at high temperatures (400–1000 °C) to produce hydrogen and carbon dioxide (e.g., CH3CH2OH + 3H2O → 6H2 + 2CO2). In dry reforming, the process generally involves the reaction of fuels with CO2 at high temperatures (700–1000 °C) to produce syngas (e.g., CH4 + CO2 → 2H2 + 2CO). While in partial oxidation, a substoichiometric fuel-air mixture at mild temperatures (250–700 °C) is used to produce hydrogen and carbon monoxide (e.g., CH3CH2OH + 0.5O2 → 3H2 + 2CO). Given the previously discussed challenges, considerable efforts have been directed toward the development of high-performance catalysts specifically designed for hydrogen production via the reforming of renewable fuels. Among emerging strategies, the use of multielemental materials, particularly those with entropy-driven design, has gained increasing attention. This approach not only enhances catalytic performance in fuel reforming but also holds promise across a broad range of applications in energy conversion and storage technologies [3,4]. Indeed, medium- and high-entropy materials (MEMs and HEMs), characterized by their compositional diversity and structural complexity, are increasingly being investigated as catalysts and electrocatalysts for energy-related applications owing to their unique physicochemical properties [5,6]. From a compositional perspective, high-entropy materials (HEMs) typically consist of five or more principal elements in approximately equiatomic ratios, whereas medium-entropy materials (MEMs) generally contain three to four major elemental components [7]. These compounds, characterized by heightened entropy, encompass diverse material classes, including alloys (MEAs and HEAs), metal hydroxides (MEHs and HEHs), metal oxides (MEOs and HEOs), and metal sulfides (MESs and HESs), among others [3]. Consequently, the emergence of MEMs and HEMs presents extensive opportunities for exploring a broad range of compositions and structural configurations, thereby enabling the design of novel materials tailored for diverse applications [8]. These materials, comprising multiple metal elements, provide a plethora of active sites and synergistic effects with varied functionalities, promoting enhanced catalytic activity. For instance, the compositional flexibility of MEMs and HEMs allows for precise tuning of catalyst properties, enabling customization for specific catalytic processes and fostering innovation in energy conversion. Crucially, the inherent stability and exceptional durability of MEMs or HEMs, arising from the entropy-driven mixing of elements, ensure robust performance under harsh catalytic conditions. For instance, in contrast to Ni-based superalloys, HEAs exhibit superior stability at elevated temperatures, reduced cost and density, and a beneficial lattice mismatch effect [9]. These characteristics highlight the potential of high-entropy alloys (HEAs) to replace conventional Ni-based superalloys as the next generation of high-temperature materials. Accordingly, the rational design of HEAs can lead to materials with outstanding physicochemical and mechanical properties [9]. These include notable resistance to wear, oxidation, and corrosion, excellent high-temperature strength, and outstanding structural and chemical stability [9]. Driven by advances in this class of materials, a new generation of catalysts with high configurational entropy has recently been developed for the reforming of renewable fuels. It is worth noticing that despite recent reviews summarizing the progress of using MEMs and/or HEMs as high-performance catalysts for overall water electrolysis [10–13], SOFCs [14–16], metal-air batteries [11], lithium-sulfur batteries [17], lithium-ion batteries, and supercapacitors [18,19], there is no previous work highlighting these emerging materials as catalysts for reforming of renewable fuels. Hence, considering the unexplored terrain in the current scientific domain, this review aims to spotlight recent advancements and trends in utilizing MEMs and HEMs as novel catalysts for regulating the reforming of renewable fuels such as bioethanol and biomethane, as summarized in Scheme 1 . Additionally, the fundamental principles and challenges associated with MEAs and HEAs as catalysts are highlighted, outlining primary synthesis protocols and strategies employed to improve electrochemical responses. This discussion correlates these properties with catalytic activity, material composition, structure, and configurational entropy. Furthermore, a critical evaluation of the advantages and limitations of employing various MEMs and HEMs is presented, along with insights into prospective directions and future avenues in this field. 2 Principles in medium- and high-entropy materials Several unique effects emerge from the mixing of multiple chemical elements when forming a single new material phase. The principal core effects are (i) high-entropy, (ii) severe lattice distortion, and (iii) cocktail effects, as elucidated in recent literature [20,21]. Each of them can be related to thermodynamics and/or kinetic effects over the catalytic activity of the MEMs and HEMs as described below. (i) High-entropy The thermodynamic stability of a crystalline phase is associated with the Gibbs free energy change (ΔG mix, where the mix is related to the mixing of elements), enthalpy, and entropy changes by the following equation: (1) Δ G m i x = Δ H m i x - T Δ S m i x Following statistical thermodynamics, the relationship between entropy and system composition can be derived from Boltzmann’s equation. The configurational entropy of mixing per mole (ΔS mix) of a crystal phase from several elements can be calculated from Eq. (2), where R is the gas constant, being 8.314 J/K mol, and x is the molar fraction of the element. (2) Δ S m i x = - R ∑ i = 1 N x i l n x i c a t i o n - s i t e + ∑ j = 1 N x j l n x j a n i o n - s i t e For a single-element phase, the ΔS mix is equal to zero. In contrast, for a three-element system, ΔS mix is ∼1.1R, and for a five-element system in equimolar proportions, ΔS mix is ∼1.61R. Based on these values, materials can be categorized as low-entropy materials (LEMs) when ΔS mix < 1.0R, medium-entropy materials (MEMs) when 1.0R < ΔS mix < 1.5R, and high-entropy materials (HEMs) when ΔS mix > 1.5R. As ΔS mix increases with the number of constituent elements (Fig. 1 a), the Gibbs free energy of mixing (ΔG mix = ΔH mix − TΔS mix) can become negative at sufficiently high temperatures, even when the enthalpy of mixing (ΔH mix) is positive. Under such conditions, the compound can be entropically stabilized, promoting the formation of a single-phase structure (Fig. 1b and c) [22,23]. It is worth noting that while all entropy-stabilized materials fall under the family of HEMs, not all HEMs exhibit entropy stabilization [24]. In fact, the main difference lies in the occurrence of a phase transition at a specific critical temperature characteristic of the entropy-driven phase (named entropy-stabilized functional materials (ESFMs)) (Fig. 1c) [23]. Since the degree of disorder of the system can be used as a determinant of its entropy, the concept of high-entropy alloys (HEAs) was expanded to embrace a wide range of materials encompassing ionic materials, coordination compounds, and ceramics. Some examples of this novel class of compounds are high-entropy hydroxides (HEHs), oxides (HEOs), perovskites (HEPs), nitrides (HENs), carbides (HECs), borides (HEBs), hydrides (HEHs), sulfides (HESs), silicides (HESis), fluorides (HEFs), phosphates (HEPO4s), oxynitrides (HEONs), carbonitrides (HECNs), and coordination compounds (HE-CCs). Among the most studied crystal structures are periclase, fluorite, perovskite, corundum, garnet, and spinel, which have attracted considerable interest due to the enhanced properties and diverse applications revealed by these HEMs [3,25–27]. Despite phase stabilization, the melting points of these materials significantly decreased due to increasing configurational entropy and the reduction in nanoparticle crystal size. This lowered melting point enhances atomic mobility, which is crucial for oxygen transport, metal exsolution, and catalyst sintering. The exsolution of nickel provides an opportunity for metal–oxygen (M–O) bonds to actively participate in the reaction, allowing isolated ions to reorganize when these bonds break. The involvement of these bonds facilitates the reduction of metals from the lattice, enabling the confinement of cations with different ionic radii within the same distorted lattice. This lattice distortion promotes the activation of active metal sites and improves catalytic performance [28]. Fig. 2 illustrates the most common crystal cells found in HEAs and HEOs, and notably, both spinels and perovskites (Fig. 2b) feature two distinct cation sites [31]. In the case of perovskites ABO3, the A and B site cation populations are well-defined due to the significantly larger ionic radius of the A cation relative to the B (Fig. 3 d) [30]. However, in spinels, there is a degree of inversion λ in the structure (A1− λ B λ )Td[A λ B2− λ ]OhO4, where it is common for cation populations to be distributed between the Tetrahedral (Td) and Octahedral (Oh) sites (Fig. 3e) [31]. For this review, it is assumed that the A and B sites of perovskites can be formally applied in Eq. (2) to calculate entropic stabilization. Conversely, for spinels, since the Td and Oh sites cannot be appropriately separated, they will be treated as a single cationic site in our calculations. Entropic stabilization can be very useful in forming phases that cannot be obtained at low temperatures, especially with dissimilar elements with very different ionic radii or charges. Such combinations could lead to improved catalytic properties, as discussed in the following sections. (ii) Severe lattice distortion The radius of a chemical element in a crystalline structure depends on its atomic number and oxidation state. Consequently, the formation of a crystalline phase with multiple elements induces distortions in the lengths of chemical bonds, thereby altering the unit cell structure and molecular orbital levels. From the canonical work of Hume-Rothery, the proposed rules to predict the compatibility of solid solutions to form binary alloys can be used to understand the extent of lattice distortion. His classical proposition of similar sizes, state of oxidation, and electronegativity offers insight into how the enthalpic contribution of the system must be counter-balanced to lead to the formation of HEMs. In that sense, transition metals with different oxidation states and from different regions of the periodic table pose a greater challenge to stabilization, thus combining the catalytic activities between rare-earth elements, alkali metals, transition metals, and so on. Another contribution is the Jahn-Teller effect in transition metal materials that can lead to lattice distortion, typically resulting in an axial elongation or compression. In particular, Cu2+ ions in octahedral coordination are expected to induce Jahn-Teller-type distortions in the surrounding O2− sublattice, resulting in a characteristic geometry of four shortened and two elongated Cu0 separations [22,32]. The configuration disorder in HEM increases the material's tendency to exhibit defects, especially vacancies. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations indicate an increase of up to 10 times in the concentration of metal vacancies in HEA [33] and of oxygen or cations in HEO [34] when compared to their low-entropy counterparts. All effects of distortion in bond lengths and angles, along with the increased number of defects, are factors that can contribute to catalytic activity by forming active sites. Particularly, the increase in oxygen vacancies leads to enhanced solid-state ionic conductivity, playing a crucial role in preventing coke formation in reforming catalysts. This is because the solid-state reaction between metal-carbon species and O2− becomes more likely, increasing the rate of CO and CO2 formation. Entropy can be visualized as a continuum, from completely random atomic distributions through increasing order into clusters or short-range ordering (Fig. 3a–c), to phase segregation ordering. Quantifying and mapping elemental distribution at the atomic level is experimentally challenging and requires high-resolution chemical mapping like Scanning transmission electron microscopy-energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (STEM-EDS) (Fig. 4 e) and site-sensitive spectroscopic analyses such as extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) [35,36] or Mössbauer spectroscopy [37], which can differentiate cation distribution across different sites. A less explored field is the increase of entropy due to the conjugation of different anions; due to the larger differences in size, charge, and electronegativity, and the lower number of high-temperature-stable anions, the combination of them is more challenging. The most common examples of anions are F−, O2−, S2−, S O 4 2 - , C O 3 2 - , and P O 4 3 - . High-entropy NASICON with structures like Na m Mt n (PO4) x O y F z poses increased sodium ionic conductivity and better cyclability in sodium-ion batteries [38,39], and another high-entropy polyanionic compound with high ionic mobility is Ca1.5Ba0.5Si5O3N6, shown to contain percolating one-dimensional (1D) Ca diffusion pathways [40]. (iii) Cocktail effect The combination of different chemical elements in a single crystal structure leads to the emergence of new and unexpected properties of materials, so the observed characteristics cannot be explained by a simple linear combination of the constituent elements, denoted as the “cocktail effect”. Several hypotheses have been proposed to explain the enhanced properties arising from the formation of multimetallic catalytic centers: the ability to adsorb different molecules that subsequently react on the solid surface (Fig. 4a); modification of molecular orbital energy levels, thereby reducing the activation energy of the rate-limiting step (Fig. 4b); cooperative action facilitating multi-electron processes, such as the four-electron reduction of molecular oxygen (Fig. 4c–e) [41,42]; concerted reaction mechanisms involving the simultaneous cleavage and formation of multiple bonds, as exemplified by ethanol oxidation in fuel cells [43] and presence of guardian atoms that inhibit deactivation or poisoning mechanisms of active atoms, all of which can be used to tune the material properties towards a desired reaction [44]. The formation of multielement catalytic centers can also enable novel synthesis routes, and combined with enhanced entropic stability at elevated temperatures, position HEMs as ideal candidates for catalytic fuel reforming. Initially, research focused on equimolar compositions to identify active phases of interest; however, recent advances integrating artificial intelligence and high-throughput synthesis techniques have significantly expanded the exploration of compositional spaces [45], accelerating the quest for tuned compositions with greater thermal stability, fuel reforming activity, and resistance to coke formation. The opportunity to generate new catalysts without rare and expensive elements such as noble metals Pt, Pd, Rh, Ru, or Ir increases the interest in the search for new highly active and stable HEMs. To address the limitations of conventional catalysts and highlight the unique advantages of HEMs, Table 1 presents a comparative summary based exclusively on the findings and references discussed in this review. In fact, it outlines how high-entropy catalysts outperform traditional systems in terms of thermodynamic and structural stability, coking resistance, vacancy concentration, compositional flexibility, and electronic structure tunability. These improvements arise from the core entropy-driven effects, namely, high configurational entropy, severe lattice distortion, and the cocktail effect, which enable the formation of single-phase multicomponent materials with superior catalytic behavior under harsh reforming conditions. 3 Reforming processes The production of hydrogen (H2) and synthesis gas (syngas, a mixture of H2 and CO) has been extensively studied and utilized in industrial processes for decades. One of the most prominent applications of syngas is as an intermediate feedstock in the Fischer-Tropsch process, which converts syngas into liquid hydrocarbons used in chemical and fuel production. Syngas can be generated from a diverse range of carbon-rich feedstocks, including natural gas, coal, biogas, and biomass [46]. Pure hydrogen finds application in ammonia production for agroindustry, as a combustible in fuel cells, is utilized as feedstock in chemical industries, and, notably, has gained prominence as a promising energy source since the energy crisis triggered by petroleum shortages in the 1970s [47,48]. Within this context, biogas has emerged as a particularly attractive methane feedstock due to its renewable nature and environmental sustainability, prompting extensive research interest. Methane from various sources can be converted into syngas and subsequently refined into hydrogen via reforming processes, which primarily include steam reforming (SRM), partial oxidation (POM), autothermal reforming (ATR), and dry reforming (DRM). While SR, POM, and ATR are well-established in industrial applications, dry reforming remains notable for its environmental and industrial potential but has yet to reach commercial maturity [49]. Biogas stands as a commendable alternative to fossil sources, constituting a gaseous mixture originating from the anaerobic decomposition of organic materials. Its production can be derived from various sources, including animal wastes, landfills, decomposing agricultural substances, and other processes that generate organic matter as a byproduct [50]. The main components of biogas are CH4 and CO2. However, depending on the organic matter source, the biogas composition is variable, containing contaminants such as H2S, NH3, N2, and humidity, which reduces the calorific power and conversion efficiency in the CH4 reforming process. The effects of contaminants in different applications of biomethane are expressed in Table 2 [51]. According to literature, the average composition of biogas includes CH4: 40 %–80 %; CO2: 24 %–40 %; H2: 1 %–3 %; N2: 0.5 %–3 %; O2: 0.1 %–1 %; H2S: 0.1 %–0.5 % and NH3: 0.1 %–5 % [52–54]. Furthermore, hydrogen and syngas production routes are predominantly based on natural gas reforming, given that these processes are well-established in industry and offer significantly lower costs compared to alternative methods. Steam reforming of methane (SRM) is the most established and widely adopted industrial process for hydrogen production, owing to its high hydrogen yield and well-established technology. The process involves the catalytic reaction of methane with steam, usually at 750–900 °C in 20–45 bar pressure, typically using a steam-to-carbon (S/C) ratio of around 3:1 is employed to suppress coke formation and drive the equilibrium toward hydrogen production [55]. The process provides a theoretical H2/CO ratio of 3:1, as exposed in Eq. (3) at the end of this section, making it suitable for applications such as ammonia synthesis and fuel cells. Hydrogen yield can be further increased by coupling SRM with the water-gas shift reaction (WGSR), elucidated by Eq. (4). Despite its industrial relevance, SRM faces several challenges. Its highly endothermic nature demands continuous heat input, often supplied externally, leading to energy inefficiencies and heat transfer losses [56]. Alternatives involving internal heat generation are being explored to improve thermal integration and reduce operational costs [57]. Additionally, catalysts commonly used in SRM are prone to deactivation, especially due to sintering and carbon deposition under harsh conditions. These issues highlight the need for advanced catalyst formulations and reactor designs that enhance stability, reduce coke formation, and improve overall process efficiency. Partial oxidation of methane (POM) is a route that involves the use of CO2 and O2 gases, as shown in Eq. (5), and it is an alternative method to produce low-cost hydrogen. Once this reaction is moderately exothermic, it operates at atmospheric pressure and temperatures between 700 and 900 °C, which ensures the complete conversion of methane. In this process, the CO selectivity has a slight decrease because methane tends to react with oxygen and form CO2 (Eq. (6)), showing a H2/CO ratio of 2 [58]. One of the key advantages of POM is its ability to operate at high space velocities, enabling compact reactor designs and efficient throughput. However, the short residence time between methane and the catalyst necessitates highly active and stable catalysts to ensure efficient conversion and selectivity [58]. A critical challenge lies in managing the exothermicity of the reaction: the localized release of heat in the catalyst bed can cause adiabatic temperature rises, leading to thermal gradients, hot spots, and ultimately catalyst deactivation [59]. Such deactivation typically results from local sintering, the formation of inactive phases via solid-solid reactions, and carbon deposition [60]. The POM route inherently produces heat within the reaction zone; however, it yields a lower H2/CO ratio compared to SR [61]. Autothermal reforming (ATR), in turn, consists of a combination of both SR and POM, resulting in a process that requires lower temperatures and O2 consumption, resulting in major H2 production, since the CH4/O2/H2O ratios are easily controlled to improve the reactor performance [62,63]. The overall reaction is described according to Eq. (7), and it might be noticed that the theoretical energy of the reaction is set to zero, and this condition is reached when the net adiabatic heat of reaction is zero. It is important to consider, in real conditions, a slight increase in O/C ratio to account for heat losses, to gas heating to the necessary temperature, to control the product composition, and limit coke formation [64]. The main aspects that make ATR interesting for industry applications are the low energy requirements, higher and easily regulated H2/CO than the POM process, and a space velocity higher than SRM. Another point of interest is that the hot spots are avoided and prevent the catalyst deactivation because of the reactor’s design [65]. From an overall perspective, dry reforming of methane (DRM) stands out for utilizing only the CO2 present in biogas as the oxidant, thereby reducing process costs [66]. In this process, the hydrogen-to-carbon ratio is approximately 2:1, similar to steam reforming (SRM). However, like SRM, dry reforming lacks an external energy source, and ongoing research aims to develop catalysts capable of lowering the energy required for methane conversion. Additional efforts focus on the development of membrane and solar-driven reactors to further minimize energy consumption [67,68]. The dry reforming reaction is represented by Eq. (8) and is particularly attractive for downstream Fischer-Tropsch synthesis due to the production of H2 and CO in an equimolar ratio. As an endothermic process, DRM requires high operating temperatures. The H2/CO ratio is critical for process optimization and varies depending on the intended application. To adjust this ratio and enhance performance, strategies include modifying the biogas composition, combining DRM with SRM (which also helps mitigate carbon deposition), or integrating DRM with POM, an exothermic process that can offset DRM's energy demands [69]. One of the main challenges in reforming processes, particularly in DRM, is controlling carbon deposition, which results from the low H2/CO ratio and leads to catalyst deactivation [70]. This deactivation remains poorly understood and difficult to predict. At moderate temperatures (<700 °C), methane cracking and CO disproportionation (Boudouard reaction), as exhibited by Eqs. (9) and (10), can occur, both of which lead to the formation of carbonaceous species that accumulate on the catalyst surface, blocking active sites and impeding reactant access. Notably, the Boudouard reaction is thermodynamically favored at lower temperatures due to its exothermic character. Conversely, at high temperatures (>800 °C), most catalysts experience significant activity loss [49,71]. Overcoming these issues requires the development of thermally stable catalysts with high selectivity toward CO and the ability to activate the C–H bond in CH4 at lower temperatures. While SRM, POM, and ATR are already industrially established, dry reforming remains a promising but still non-commercial technology, notable for its environmental and industrial potential [49]. It may be noticed that the CO and H2 production are influenced by the water gas shift reaction (WGSR) (Eq. (4), Table 3 ) or the reverse water gas shift (RWGS) occurrence. All the equations mentioned herein are expressed in Table 3, as well as the corresponding reaction and entropy associated. When the WGSR is favored, hydrogen production exceeds that of carbon monoxide, resulting in an H2/CO ratio greater than 1, which is advantageous for the reforming process. Conversely, when the RWGS predominates, the H2/CO ratio falls below 1, indicating a higher formation of CO relative to H2 [72]. In addition, the CO2 methanation (Eq. (11), Table 3) is a side reaction to avoid once this reaction reduces the kinetics of the reforming, and it can be suppressed using a selective catalyst [73]. While conventional reforming processes such as SMR, POM, and ATR have reached industrial maturity, DRM continues to pose significant challenges due to its highly endothermic nature and the susceptibility to catalyst deactivation via coke deposition and nanoparticle sintering. State-of-the-art Ni-based catalysts illustrate these constraints, despite efforts to enhance performance via support doping strategies. For instance, Lara-Garcia et al. [74] synthesized Ni/Ce1− x Nd x O2− δ catalysts (x = 0–0.2) by complexing Ce3+ and Nd3+ nitrates in an aqueous solution with EDTA and citric acid, each dissolved separately in ammonium hydroxide (28 %–30 % NH4OH). The two solutions were then combined and heated to 90 °C under continuous stirring until the pH stabilized around 7. The resulting gel was then dried at 65 °C and calcined at 600 °C for 4 h in air. Ni loading (5 wt %) was performed via wet impregnation of Ni(NO3)3, followed by drying at 65 °C and calcination at 600 °C for 4 h in air flow. Structural analysis revealed a fluorite cubic structure preserved after Nd doping, with lattice parameter expansion from 5.4119 to 5.4490 Å when 20 at % of Nd was introduced, promoting increased oxygen vacancies. Besides, crystallite size decreased with higher Nd content from 18.77 nm down to 12.28 nm. Raman spectroscopy confirmed F2g shifts consistent with rising extrinsic and intrinsic oxygen vacancies. Surface area calculated from Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET theory) increased from ∼33 m2/g (Ni/CeO2) to ∼41 m2/g (Ni/Ce0.80Nd0.20O2− δ ), with a bimodal Ce1− x Nd x O2− δ mesoporous support structure (3.5 nm and 16–18 nm pores). Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) analyses revealed a porous texture with some NiO particles, though Ni impregnation partially occluded pores. Ni/CeO2 catalytic tests (gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) 48,000 h−1; CH4:CO2 = 1:1; 600–800 °C) showed higher initial CH4 conversions of ∼40 % (700 °C) and ∼70 % (800 °C), and a maximum H2/CO ratio of ∼0.9 at 800 °C. However, rapid deactivation ensues (∼38 % drop over 24 h at 700 °C, from 40 % down to 25 %). Conversely, Ni/Ce0.95Nd0.05O2 − δ catalyst exhibited superior stability (∼9 % drop over 24 h at 700 °C, from 64 % down to 57 %), higher initial CH4 conversions of 64 % (700 °C) and 85 % (800 °C), and a maximum H2/CO ratio of ∼1.0 at 800 °C and lower coke deposition (O2-TPO: 0.101 mmol CO2 vs. 0.436 mmol CO2 for Ni/CeO2) underscoring the role of oxygen vacancies in mitigating coke formation. At the mechanistic level, the Ni/Ce1− x Nd x O2 − δ catalysts facilitate DRM through a synergistic effect where CH4 activation occurs predominantly at metallic Ni0 sites, while CO2 activation and carbon gasification are mediated by oxygen vacancies in the Ce-Nd-O lattice. The vacancies act as reservoirs for lattice oxygen that oxidizes deposited carbon species (C + O(lattice) → CO), thereby suppressing coke accumulation. Additionally, the Nd-induced modification of CeO2 reduces surface basicity at higher dopant levels, slightly compromising CO2 adsorption and activation, which explains the superior performance of Ni/Ce0.95Nd0.05O2- δ compared to higher Nd loadings. This delicate balance between redox capacity and acid-base properties ensures optimal DRM activity and enhanced catalyst stability. In contrast, Shao et al. [75] reported a HEO catalyst [(MgCoNiMnFe)O x /ZrO2] that marks a paradigm shift in DRM catalysis. Synthesized via co-precipitation of metal nitrates in NaOH, followed by two-stage calcination (500 °C/2 h, 900 °C/2 h), this HEO exhibited a homogeneous halite structure with equimolar cation distribution. EDS and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) confirmed uniform dispersion, while electron microscopy analyses revealed a porous morphology (∼50 nm grains) intimately mixing HEO, spinel, and monoclinic-ZrO2 phases. Performance in chemical looping DRM (CL-DRM) at 800 °C over 100 cycles demonstrated CH4 and CO2 conversions of ∼43 %–45 % with syngas selectivity up to 97 % and an H2/CO ratio of ∼1.0. XAFS/XPS analyses revealed dynamic exsolution-redissolution of NiFeCo nanoalloys, which catalyze CH4 activation (C–H bond cleavage) and suppress filamentous coke via lattice oxygen exchange. Unlike monometallic Ni catalysts, HEO/ZrO2 exhibited negligible carbon deposition as supported by Raman, even under shortened regeneration cycles, underscoring the entropy-stabilized matrix's role in maintaining structural integrity and preventing sintering. At the mechanistic level, the (MgCoNiMnFe)O x /ZrO2 catalyst facilitates DRM through a dual redox cycle where CH4 is activated by exsolved NiFeCo nanoalloys for C–H bond cleavage, while lattice oxygen from the halite HEO matrix oxidizes deposited carbon species, preventing coke accumulation. CO2 regeneration replenishes lattice oxygen via the reverse Boudouard reaction and CO2 splitting (CO2 + C → 2CO), sustaining catalyst activity across cycles and stabilizing the halite matrix against phase segregation. This synergy between exsolved metal sites and the high-entropy oxide lattice ensures efficient methane reforming and CO2 utilization with minimal sintering and deactivation. To better illustrate the distinct reaction mechanisms occurring on conventional Ni-based catalysts and HEO systems during DRM, Fig. 5 provides a visual comparison between CH4 and CO2 activation, H2 and CO formation, and carbon gasification routes across both catalytic platforms. This representation highlights the role of lattice oxygen and the exsolved NiFeCo nanoalloys in enabling cyclic redox activity and coke suppression in HEO-based catalysts. These results underscore the inherent advantages of HEOs. The lattice distortion and sluggish atomic diffusion characteristic of these materials enhance the structural stability of active sites, while their multicomponent architecture facilitates cyclic oxygen exchange. This dual effect mitigates coke formation and nanoparticle sintering, both major limitations in conventional DRM catalysts. Consequently, HEOs stand out as highly promising candidates for robust, long-term operation under the harsh conditions of industrial DRM. The performance gap outlined in Table 4 below highlights a fundamental divergence in catalyst design. Traditional Ni-based systems depend predominantly on monometallic Ni0 sites for CH4 activation, making them particularly vulnerable to deactivation through carbon deposition and particle agglomeration. In contrast, HEO catalysts leverage their compositional complexity to stabilize active sites via lattice distortion and sluggish diffusion, while supporting dynamic exsolution and re-dissolution of NiFeCo nanoalloys during redox cycles. This unique “cocktail effect” not only sustains catalytic activity but also imparts intrinsic resistance to coking and sintering. Altogether, the integration of entropy-stabilized materials into DRM catalysis represents a transformative advance in addressing long-standing challenges. The synergy between multicomponent lattice effects, enhanced oxygen mobility, and exceptional structural integrity positions HEOs as leading candidates for next-generation syngas production from CH4 and CO2, particularly in biogas valorization, where catalyst longevity and resilience are paramount. When evaluating the levelized cost of hydrogen (LCOH), the methane reforming ranks the lowest across different sources, IEA reports range between 0.7 and 1.6 USD/kgH2 in 2020 [76], despite its high greenhouse gas emissions of 10.8 kgCO2/kgH2 [77]. The catalyst itself typically represents only a minor fraction of the total cost, and the dominant contributors to LCOH are the cost of the feedstock, whether natural gas, biomethane, or ethanol, along with energy input and capital expenditure of the industrial plant [78]. NiO supported over metal oxides catalysts are widely used in BASF [79], Clariant [80], among others, due to their low material costs and reasonable performance, whereas noble metal catalysts such as Pt or Rh, although highly active and stable, face significant limitations due to their scarcity and elevated prices, as July/2025: Ni 18 USD/kg, Pt 32,000 USD/kg, Rh 300,000 USD/kg. HEMs composed of multicomponent metal oxides or alloys offer a promising alternative with the potential for further cost reduction, as their composition can be tailored to substitute metals like Ni or Co with less costly alternatives such as Fe and Mn, altogether improving performance. Despite the relatively low contribution of catalyst cost to LCOH, high-entropy catalysts could significantly reduce hydrogen production costs. By enabling operation at lower temperatures, since conventional SMR is typically carried out at 900 °C for maximum efficiency, requiring high thermal input and the use of expensive reactor alloys such as Inconel, rich in expensive metals such as Ni, Co, Ti, Ta, and Nb. If reforming can be sustained below 600 °C using HEM catalysts, the process could benefit from lower thermal losses and enable the use of more affordable alloys such as SS310, protected with hydrogen-resistant coatings. This could lead to substantial Capital Expenditure (CAPEX) reductions and lower heat generation costs. HEMs exhibit excellent catalytic activity for SMR and related reforming processes at temperatures ranging from 500 to 900 °C. Furthermore, the enhanced structural stability and resistance to deactivation typical of HEM could lead to extended catalyst lifetimes and reduced operational downtime. By minimizing the frequency of regeneration cycles or catalyst replacement, HEMs may contribute to significant Operational Expenditure (OPEX) reductions. In a hypothetical scenario where catalyst longevity matches the 25 years of the reforming plant, the reactor designs could be simplified by eliminating seals and ports required for periodic catalyst replacement. While these theoretical advantages are compelling, the literature currently lacks robust, comparative studies of LCOH integrating different catalyst systems under realistic industrial conditions. Future work must address this gap through techno-economic modeling and life cycle assessment of full-scale hydrogen production plants employing distinct catalytic materials capable of reducing LCOH and greenhouse gas emissions. From a fuel perspective, ethanol [28,81,82] and methanol [81] are promising hydrogen carriers [81,83]. Hydrogen can be produced from diverse alcohol reforming routes, and the incorporation of bioethanol into the distribution networks of the United States and Brazil [83,84] has been steadily increasing via the SR process, which is predominantly used in industrial applications, and has been increasing through the years by the SR route, as it is mostly industrially applicable. The United States and Brazil are the largest producers of ethanol, together accounting for 80 % of the world's production, as shown in Fig. 6 (a) [85]. Notably, ethanol production in the United States relies primarily on corn fermentation, while in Brazil, sugarcane serves as the main feedstock. Methanol, in turn, can be obtained by multiple routes [81,86]. However, the most economically viable way is from syngas derived from natural gas. This reliance on fossil-based feedstock limits the scalability of methanol as a sustainable bioenergy source. Eq. (18) describes the primary methanol synthesis reaction, and for a reforming process, the most common route to produce syngas is by the steam reforming route, as described in Eq. (19). Biogas production and biomethane reforming primarily utilize energy derived from urban and rural organic waste to feed biodigesters. According to Fig. 6(b) [87], European countries and China collectively represent most of the market share, with contributions of 45 % and 22 %, respectively. This predominance can be attributed to the substantial generation of scalable organic waste in these regions due to their high demographic concentration, which supports the viability and efficiency of hydrogen production from biogas feedstock. 4 Medium- and high-entropy materials-based catalysts The scientific and industrial communities recognize the vast potential for catalysts of diverse structures and compositions to play a pivotal role in the ongoing energy transition. Particularly, in the realm of catalysts aimed at hydrogen production from strategically reforming renewable fuels, this understanding is well-established. In fact, among the notable advancements reported, the development of Ni-based catalysts shows considerable promise due to their commendable performance and affordable cost [88]. Despite this potential, these catalysts often face challenges such as sintering and coking at elevated reaction temperatures [89]. These challenges impose limitations on the application of these catalysts, often requiring precise control over operating conditions, strict restrictions on contaminants that could poison the catalyst, specific regeneration protocols, and frequent replacement of the catalytic bed after deactivation. Considering the challenges discussed above, numerous strategies have been explored to develop more efficient catalysts. A recent and promising approach involves designing catalysts composed of two or more metals [88]. Interestingly, the design of such catalysts has required the preparation of more complex compounds, encompassing materials with even higher configurational entropy, where the synergistic contribution of several elements has proven to be essential for improving several properties. In fact, the concept of augmenting configurational entropy has been extensively utilized across various materials, notably alloys and metal oxides featuring diverse crystalline structures and compositions. This application extends to processes such as methane, natural gas, methanol, ethanol, and, more recently, biogas, biomethane, and bioethanol reforming, as summarized in Tables 5 and 6 , and promising results have been unveiled. The deliberate incorporation of diverse metal cations in MEOs/HEOs has shown a propensity to amplify catalytic performance by presenting an array of active sites with varying chemical environments known as the cocktail effect [20]. This diversity in active sites, coupled with the inherent stability arising from the high configurational entropy, has positioned MEOs/HEOs as promising candidates for catalyzing a myriad of chemical transformations, unlike traditional oxides that typically consist of one or two dominant metal species [17]. Recently, researchers have embarked on a quest to harness the benefits of high-entropy configurations for improving these oxides with an assortment of tunable properties that hold immense promises for catalytic applications in methane, ethanol, and biogas reforming. Within the domain of MEOs and HEOs design, several structural frameworks and synthesis methodologies have gained widespread adoption. Recent advancements highlight the promising potential of two prominent approaches in the fabrication of high- and medium-entropy catalysts: first, the use of perovskite-like oxide structures, particularly through metal modifications at the B-site, offers a robust alternative for developing stable catalysts via well-established synthesis routes such as sol-gel and coprecipitation methods. Second, medium- to high-entropy layered double hydroxides (ME-LDHs/HE-LDHs) as precursors for various categories of MEOs and HEOs, particularly in the realm of catalysts built upon spinel and periclase-type oxide structures. This innovative approach leverages the unique properties of LDHs to enable the controlled synthesis of MEOs and HEOs with diverse compositions and structures. Utilizing these precursor materials has proven instrumental in engineering MEOs and HEOs with specific crystal phases and morphologies, which are crucial for catalytic applications. The sol-gel synthesis route, widely explored to produce the medium- and high-entropy catalysts studied in this work, consists of the solubilization of metal ions from the precursor’s hydrolysis in a polymeric framework [90]. This method favors the homogeneous dispersion of metal species and single-phase stability, which is beneficial to the catalytic activity of the MEM or HEM due to the effective distribution of active sites. Moreover, the gel drying parameters provide suitable control over catalyst morphology, such as surface area and porosity, making it an adequate and well-established route for developing highly efficient and structurally tunable catalytic materials [91]. Coprecipitation method, in turn, involves the simultaneous precipitation of multiple metal precursors under controlled pH and temperature conditions, promoting the formation of homogeneous multicomponent hydroxides. Subsequent controlled calcination leads to the development of single-phase solid solutions, a key requirement for stabilizing the entropy-driven structures characteristic of MEM or HEM [92]. Structurally, coprecipitation favors the formation of nanoscale crystallites and enhances metal-metal interactions, improving the catalyst selectivity [93]. From a catalytic standpoint, MEM or HEM catalysts synthesized via coprecipitation exhibit enhanced activity due to the uniform distribution of active sites, which also contributes to improved recyclability and reversibility of exsolution processes. Furthermore, the method offers strong advantages in terms of scalability and reproducibility, making it highly suitable for practical applications [94]. Notably, the principal compositions obtained through the aforementioned methods include the prevalence of Ni-containing medium- and high-entropy systems as catalysts for hydrogen production, as expected for an active element exhibiting the aforementioned distinctive characteristics. Interestingly, the catalytic performance of Ni is significantly enhanced in high- and medium-entropy alloys (HEAs/MEAs) compared to traditional unary and binary systems [71]. Ni acts as a key active site for C–H bond activation in reforming reactions, and the multicomponent environment of HEAs/MEAs stabilizes Ni in oxidation states and coordination environments that promote higher turnover frequencies (TOF) and resistance to sintering. Unlike binary systems, which often suffer from phase segregation or limited electronic tunability, entropy-stabilized matrices provide uniform atomic dispersion and synergistic electronic interactions among multiple elements, modulating the d-band center of Ni and thereby enhancing its catalytic activity and selectivity [95]. For instance, He and his colleagues [71] reported a catalyst that prevents methane cracking and, consequently, the CO disproportionation reaction by coating Ni nanoparticles with a thin layer of a ternary Ni-Mg-Al system. Stability tests demonstrated that the catalyst remained active for 300 h, maintaining methane conversion close to the equilibrium level (∼80 % of CH4 conversion) under reaction conditions of CH4/CO2/N2 = 1:1:3, a GHSV of 20,000 mL/h/gcat, and a temperature of 800 °C [71]. Shao et al. [75] explored the methane chemical looping of a HE-catalyst performance [(MgCoNiMnFe)O x ], which remained stable by 100 cycles with a methane conversion of 48 % in the 100th cycle to the (MgNiMnFe)O x catalyst. In this same work, the authors discuss the pivotal role of Ni in CH4 activation by comparing the performance of 6 % CH4 conversion of (MgCoMnFe)O x to the other reported catalysts’ performance and the contribution of Mg and Mn as promoters for 3d transition metals. Other elements such as Al, Mg, Co, La, and Fe were also used and highlighted, even though some of them are used in more specific phases, such as Ba and Sr. Conversely, beyond composition, structure stands out as another crucial variable within the domain of catalysis, particularly propelled by materials characterized by medium- and high-entropy. For instance, different properties can be intentionally modulated for the different oxide phases, such as perovskite, spinel, and periclase structures, especially by increasing the entropy of the system. The following sections present recent advances in medium- and high-entropy materials (MEMs and HEMs) designed for hydrogen production within these assembled structures, specifically focusing on methane, ethanol, biogas, and methanol reforming. 4.1 Medium- and high-entropy perovskite oxides (MEPs/HEPs) Perovskite-type oxides have been extensively studied as catalysts for hydrogen production. For example, Bian et al. [96] reviewed the perovskite catalysts for the reforming of methane to hydrogen production, focusing especially on low-entropy perovskite. A typical perovskite oxide (ABO3) comprises a 12-fold coordinated A cation site, a 6-fold coordinated B cation site, and an octahedral O2− sublattice [97]. The A-site is typically occupied by an alkali, alkaline earth, or rare earth metal cation, while the B-site is a transition metal cation. Elevating entropy through the substitution of multiple cation types with different ionic radii at comparable molar concentrations within A- and/or B-sites induces notable lattice distortion [98,99]. This distortion arises from chemical disorder, resulting in atomic size mismatch or distinct charge transfer processes [99]. It is notable to specify that high-entropy perovskites (HEPs) are characterized as perovskite-type materials with a minimum of 5 elements occupying either the A or B site and a stabilization factor ΔS > 1.5R, according to Eq. (2). Whereas medium-entropy perovskites (MEPs) are delineated by these sites housing 3 or 4 elements, and ΔS in the range from 1.0R to 1.5R [98]. The substitution of M3+ cations with M2+ can induce the formation of new oxygen vacancies to maintain the charge balance of the ABO3− δ structure. This property is widely exploited by employing alkaline earth metals in the A-site, such as Ba2+ and Sr2+ , in association with rare earth cations, such as La3+. These vacancies enhance the ionic conductivity of the perovskite phase, enabling it to supply oxygen anions for catalytic reforming, which are then regenerated through the adsorption and reaction of H2O or CO2 [100]. The electronic and catalytic properties are usually strongly dependent on B-site modifications since it has the smaller transition metals like nickel, cobalt, iron, manganese, and copper [83,101–105]. The performance of the active site depends strongly on the element’s combination due to synergistic contributions and the cocktail effect. For example, Mn is such a good combination with Ni due to its crystallinity and surface activity [102] obtained by Ni exsolution, commonly observed in LaSrMnNi and LaCeMnNi [105,106]. Co-Fe catalysts have shown good thermal stability and anti-coking properties due to LaFeO3 formation [104]. As the reduction atmosphere is high for SRE/OSRE, there is a tendency for cobalt to be reduced to nanometallic cobalt and strongly disperse on the surface [104], increasing the catalytic activity. Interestingly, HEPs have recently been designed as highly active oxygen carriers (OC) with decorated nanoparticles for chemical looping dry reforming of methane (CL-DRM) [97]. In this study, the high-entropy concept was achieved by substituting both the A and B sites, resulting in different formulations based on La0.35Sr0.35Ba0.30Fe1− x Co x O3− δ (Table 5), where the best substitution proportion of Co was set in the range of 0.4–0.6, with ΔS = 1.58R. Nanoparticles adhering to the perovskite structure become established on the sample surface through a synthetic process predominantly reliant on exsolution (Fig. 7 a), since during the reduction step, the synthesis of Fe nanoparticles is favored when Fe cations are substituted by Co (as confirmed by EDS mapping, Fig. 7b). Through this synthetic approach, nanoparticle exsolution transpires within a reducing environment, positing that nanoparticle formation correlates with their reduction potential as a governing factor [107]. The introduction of Co substitution can significantly diminish the perovskite lattice, facilitating the migration of Fe ions and the subsequent formation of Fe nanoparticles. This process notably enhances the activation of CH4, thereby facilitating its further conversion. In fact, the CH4 conversion was 84.3 %, and the syngas yield was 15.23 mmol/g in the CH4 reduction step for the La0.35Sr0.35Ba0.3Fe0.6Co0.4O3 OC with excellent redox stability and activation (Fig. 7c). These characteristics exemplify the potential of the novel perovskite materials containing anchored nanoparticles as promising oxygen carriers for the CL-DRM process. The coarsening of catalysts, often resulting in the aggregation of nanoparticles, is a major deactivation pathway in catalytic systems [71,108,109]. Various strategies have been explored to mitigate this issue, with the exsolution of nanoparticles strongly anchored to the parental phase emerging as one of the most promising [110]. In perovskite-based catalysts, B-site metals can be exsolved under reductive atmospheres, and the metal composition plays a crucial role in this process (Fig. 8 a, b). For instance, Oh et al. extended the concept of triple-phase boundaries (TPB) from electrochemistry to catalytic reforming. In their study, NiFe nanoparticles were exsolved from the medium-entropy perovskite La0.9Ca0.1Fe x Ni1− x O3− δ . They found that the TPB, defined as the interface between the alloy, the perovskite, and the gaseous reactants, was the most active site for the dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction. Moreover, the crystalline phases work synergistically with the NiFe alloy, acting as a Lewis base, performing the oxidative addition of methane and C–H cleavage, while the perovskite parent phase acts as a Lewis acid, adsorbing CO2. The degree of exsolution and TPB elongation were shown to be tunable by varying the Fe substitution ratio in the perovskite oxide. Significantly, the highest entropy perovskite composition (LCFN55 (Ni0.5Fe0.5)) exhibited the most elongated TPB (Fig. 8c, d) and achieved unprecedented CO2 and CH4 conversions of 95 % and 91 %, respectively. These exceptional results were maintained over 1000 h under non-diluted conditions without deactivation, showcasing the role of entropy stabilization in mitigating nanoparticle coarsening and maintaining catalytic activity. By adjusting the Fe ratio, the degree of exsolution and the TPB activity were effectively controlled, underscoring the potential for tailoring catalytic properties through compositional tuning in high entropy materials. This trend is further supported by Mallikarjun et al. [111], who investigated La1− x Sr x Ni0.80Zr0.20O3 (x = 0.1–0.8) perovskites synthesized via a sol-gel route for CO2-steam bi-reforming of methane (BRM). The optimized catalyst, La0.80Sr0.20Ni0.80Zr0.20O3, exhibited a CH4 conversion of 88.8 %, CO2 conversion of 77.8 %, and an H2 yield of 70.2 % at 800 °C, with a syngas H2/CO ratio from 1.5 to 2.0 depending on reaction conditions. These outstanding results were attributed to the interplay of structural and morphological features: X-Ray diffraction (XRD) and H2-temperature programed reduction (TPR) analyses revealed that moderate Sr substitution enhanced metal-support interactions and stabilized smaller Ni crystallites, while excessive Sr led to La2NiO4 spinel formation and SrCO3 surface species that blocked active sites. SEM and BET measurements confirmed increased dispersion and surface area in the La0.80Sr0.20Ni0.80Zr0.20O3 sample, while CO2-temperature programed desorption (TPD) demonstrated enhanced surface basicity, favoring CO2 adsorption and activation. The thermal treatment at 800 °C ensured phase purity and robust catalyst architecture, minimizing sintering and coke deposition, as evidenced by time-on-stream analysis showing stable performance over 100 h with negligible carbon formation. These findings reinforce the importance of synthesis strategy, dopant concentration, microstructural engineering, and catalyst-support synergy in determining the activity, selectivity, and durability of medium- and high-entropy perovskites for CH4 reforming applications [111]. This discussion is further enriched by the work of Yao et al. [112], who investigated PrBaMn1.60Ni0.30Fe0.10O5+ δ double-layer perovskites with exsolved Ni-Fe alloy nanoparticles as highly stable catalysts for CO2 DRM. The exsolved Ni0.15Fe0.05 catalyst exhibited a CH4 conversion of 80 %–83 %, CO2 conversion of 75 %–79 %, and a tunable H2/CO ratio between 0.85 and 1.1 at 800 °C under both atmospheric and high-pressure (14 bar) conditions, maintaining activity for 260 h on stream without deactivation. This performance was attributed to the in-situ exsolution process achieved via a single-step reduction at 800 °C, which anchored Ni-Fe nanoparticles (∼21 nm) within the perovskite matrix, as confirmed by STEM-EDS and XAFS analyses. The strong metal-support interaction minimized sintering and coke deposition, with the exsolved Ni0.15Fe0.05 catalyst showing a dramatically lower apparent coke formation rate of 4.71 × 10−8 mmol/gcat/s compared to monometallic counterparts. Furthermore, XPS and EELS analyses revealed a higher concentration of surface oxygen species, facilitating CO2 activation and carbon removal. DFT calculations confirmed that Fe incorporation into the Ni lattice weakens the binding of carbon intermediates, thereby suppressing coke formation and enhancing catalyst longevity. Altogether, these results underscore the critical role of synthesis methodology, thermal treatment, and controlled exsolution in designing robust high-entropy perovskite systems with superior catalytic performance and stability under industrially relevant DRM conditions [112]. 4.2 Medium- and high-entropy hydrotalcite-type precursors Hydrotalcite-type structures consist of positively charged brucite-like layered-double hydroxides (LDHs) with interlayer regions containing anions and structural water molecules [113]. Formally, the compound structure is described by the general formula [M1− x 2+M x 3+(OH)2]( x +)(A n −) x / n ⋅mH2O [114,115], where M2+ and M3+ represent bivalent and trivalent metal cations, respectively, and A n − are the compensating interlayer anions, with x typically ranging from 0.2 to 0.4 depending on the ion used for charge balance. A detailed model of the structure architecture is shown in Fig. 9 , along with a micrograph illustrating the formation of the layered-double hydroxide [113,116]. For catalytic applications, nitrates and acetates are commonly employed as charge-balancing anions due to their excellent performance in active oxide catalysts and selective oxidation processes. They act as precursors for the catalytically active phase generated by the decomposition of hydrotalcite-like compounds [117]. The primary metals explored for catalytic applications in the bivalent site include Mg2+, Ni2+, Cu2+, and Zn2+, while cations such as Al3+, Co3+, Fe3+, and Cr3+ are used in the trivalent site. These choices are reported in recent literature [113,117–120] due to the convergence of these elements’ catalytic properties and their compatibility with cationic sites. Additionally, periclase and spinel structures derived from the thermal decomposition of hydrotalcite have become a trend in this field. The use of LDH precursors to produce medium- and high-entropy catalysts offers significant advantages compared to other routes, including thermal stability, large specific surfaces, and homogeneity of active sites [120]. These characteristics are crucial for enhancing catalytic performance, particularly in terms of conversion efficiency and hydrogen selectivity [118]. Notably, the thermal decomposition of the precursor results in a high specific surface area and active sites in the mixed metal oxides due to the removal of interlayer compounds and water. Overall, changes in the structure lead to modifications in the conversion parameters, pore size, pore volume, oxygen lattices, catalytic activity, and stability. The inclusion of Ni in the formulation of ME- and HE hydrotalcite-type precursors is a promising approach to improve combustible reforming and hydrogen selectivity. Fang and colleagues [84] have reported that the medium entropy hydrotalcite-type precursor catalyst significantly reduces carbon deposition on the catalyst surface, which is one of the biggest challenges when dealing with nickel in the catalyst compositions. Moreover, the same authors reported high H2 production (60 L/h/gcat) at a very low temperature in the OSRE configuration (50 °C) by reducing the catalyst surface, forming an Mg2AlNi X H Z O Y oxyhydride active catalyst [118]. Another study that achieved remarkable results using a hydrotalcite-type precursor was reported by An and colleagues [120]. The authors achieved complete ethanol conversion and stable H2 production for 19 h by tailoring SiO2@NiCuMgAl from LDH calcination. A complete cocktail effect could be tailored with each metal acting in a specific role. While the nickel is the main catalyst center, sintering was reduced by the entropy increase with copper addition, compared to NiAl-LDH. The presence of Mg2+ in the catalyst balanced the acidity of sites produced by Al3+, mitigating ethanol dehydration reactions and the formation of byproducts, thus reducing carbon deposition to negligible levels and enhancing catalyst stability. Additionally, Mg2+ increased water adsorption in the precursor interlayer region and facilitated oxygen anion transport to sustain the reforming reaction. This perspective is further supported by Li et al. [44], who developed high-entropy spinel-type catalysts (HE-MgAlO) derived from LDHs for bi-reforming of model biogas. The HE-MgAlO catalyst, synthesized via a one-step co-precipitation method and calcined at 700 °C, exhibited an outstanding initial CH4 conversion of 99 %, CO2 conversion of 55 %, and a tunable H2/CO ratio near 2, optimal for downstream methanol synthesis. Notably, the catalyst maintained high activity over 100 h of continuous operation, with the CH4 conversion declining only slightly to 89 %, and showed excellent resistance to coke formation and sintering. Electron microscopy analysis revealed that the LDH precursor decomposition yielded a mesoporous nanosheet-like morphology (∼200 nm) and a uniform dispersion of quinary metal cations (Ni, Co, Zn, Ga, and Mn) in the spinel matrix, confirmed by EDS mapping. The high BET surface area (106 m2/g) and pore volume (0.58 cm3/g) facilitated active site accessibility and reactant diffusion. XPS and CO2-TPD characterizations indicated enriched electron density at Ni sites and increased medium-strong basicity, both crucial for CH4 activation and CO2 adsorption. Furthermore, the strong metal-support interaction observed in H2-TPR profiles contributed to enhanced anti-sintering properties. These findings emphasize how LDH-derived precursors, combined with optimized thermal treatment, play a pivotal role in tailoring the microstructure, dispersion of active species, and stability of high-entropy catalysts, leading to superior performance in bi-reforming applications [44]. Further supporting the role of LDH precursors, Tanios et al. [121] reported the development of Ni-Co-Mg-Al mixed oxide catalysts synthesized via the hydrotalcite route for dry reforming of biogas. The catalysts, prepared through co-precipitation and calcination at 800 °C, achieved impressive CH4 conversion of 92 % and CO2 conversion of 88 % at 800 °C, with the Ni-Co bimetallic system (Co2Ni2Mg2Al2O9) outperforming monometallic counterparts. The syngas produced exhibited an H2/CO ratio close to 1.0, suitable for downstream applications. This performance was attributed to the transformation of LDH precursors into highly dispersed spinel-type phases (NiAl2O4, CoAl2O4, and MgAl2O4) and solid solutions, as confirmed by XRD and BET analyses. The resulting catalysts displayed large surface areas up to 170 m2/g and mesoporous structures that enhanced reactant diffusion and accessibility to active sites. Electron microscopy images and EDS mapping revealed a homogeneous distribution of Ni and Co nanoparticles within the oxide matrix, which contributed to resistance against sintering and carbon deposition. Additionally, the basic Mg-Al-O support promoted CO2 adsorption, facilitating coke suppression via reverse Boudouard reactions. These results further emphasize how LDH-based precursors, combined with tailored thermal treatments and compositional engineering, enable the design of high-entropy catalytic systems with outstanding activity, selectivity, and durability under biogas reforming conditions. 4.3 Medium- and high-entropy oxide (spinel and periclase-type) In a notable study, He and colleagues [71] adopted an intriguing and innovative method to craft a robust Ni catalyst free from coke deposition, achieving stabilization through an MEO layer (Fig. 10 a). In the conventional process, the Ni particles are deposited onto the MgO-Al2O matrix derived from the Ni-Mg-Al hydrotalcite, measuring approximately 30 nm in lateral size and boasting a thickness of less than 1 nm. Each Ni particle was uniformly enveloped by a superficial MEO thin layer (MEO@Ni/MgO-Al2O3), as depicted in Fig. 10(b), characterized by a thickness ranging between 1 and 2 nm. This outer layer comprised a blend of Ni, Mg, Al, and Si elements. Such material design enables stable operation within the temperature range of 873–1073 K while maintaining a stoichiometric CH4/CO2 ratio of 1.0 (Fig. 10c). According to the authors, the Ni nanoparticles struck a balance between carbon decomposition and elimination rates. Besides, the in-situ-evolved MEO layer exhibits characteristics akin to those found in HEOs (Fig. 10d), which play a pivotal role in stabilizing the Ni particles, particularly those possessing suitable sizes (∼15 nm) and high-index facets. As a result, the coke deposition was minimal and easily removed from the MEO surface by the fast reverse Boudouard Reaction (Eq. (11), Table 3). This effect of entropy-driven stabilization provides a straightforward method to precisely engineer durable and efficient metal catalysts capable of operating across a broad temperature range, suitable for a multitude of demanding reactions. Among periclase-like structures [116,120,122], there has been noted the presence of Cu [120,122], Mg [118,120], and Al [116,120,122] has been noted in some of the catalysts reviewed. The argumentation of the periclase phase structure is the dispersive properties of the pure oxides, especially NiO-CuO (active sites), and MgO-AlO (support sites), which may lead to better interaction between these species with the reactants. In fact, Mg-Al catalysts tend to promote the dispersion of the oxides on the surface [116], and combining them with the synergetic effect of Cu-Ni [120], there was an increase in catalyst deactivation resistance. Hence, there is a clear association of Ni sintering with the deactivation of the catalyst. It has also been reported that Mg-Al interactions are very strong, and the stability of those catalysts may come from the incorporation of Ni2+ cations between the Mg-(Al)-O phases [82], due to smaller cation ratio of Ni2+(0.069) besides Mg2+(0.072 nm), there is a possibility of having some extra interatomic space, leading to the formation of lattices which increases oxygen transport, and consequently, reaction efficiency [82]. The addition of Cu weakened the sintering of Ni and promoted a certain degree of water-gas shift reaction. Hence, it has good water adsorption properties [120]. These combinations must be studied and known since there are some ratios that may not be as successful as others, such as the effect of Cu-Mn observed in La-Sr-Mn-Cu [102]. Replacing Cu with Ni, there is a complete ethanol conversion, while the use of copper has decreased the conversion of the catalyst to 25 %. Ni-based catalysts can be formulated aiming at the production of non-amorphous carbon filaments, which can be less prone to blocking the active sites when compared to amorphous carbon [82]. A similar approach was adopted by Dahdah et al. [123], who prepared Ni x Mg6− x Al2 and Ni x Mg6− x Al1.80La0.20 catalysts via co-precipitation of hydrotalcite-like precursors, followed by calcination at 800 °C. The resulting materials exhibited a well-defined periclase structure (Mg(Ni,Al)O), as confirmed by XRD, with NiO, MgO, and MgNiO2 phases uniformly dispersed in the matrix. The addition of La led to the formation of La2O3 and La2NiO4 species, enhancing oxygen mobility and basicity, as evidenced by CO2-TPD profiles and FTIR spectra. The optimized Ni2Mg4Al1.80La0.20 catalyst achieved impressive CH4 and CO2 conversions of ∼80 % at 800 °C, maintaining a stable H2/CO ratio near 1.0 over 14 h of continuous operation under a GHSV of 60,000 mL/g/h. SEM and TEM analyses revealed highly dispersed Ni nanoparticles and a porous oxide matrix that minimized sintering and carbon deposition. The strong NiO-MgO interaction in the periclase lattice, further strengthened by La doping, contributed to the enhanced thermal stability and suppression of graphitic carbon formation. These findings highlight how periclase-type structures derived from LDH precursors, combined with tailored thermal treatments and strategic doping, enable the development of robust catalysts with excellent activity, selectivity, and long-term stability for DRM. 4.4 Medium- and high-entropy alloys (MEAs/HEAs) As previously addressed in the preceding subtopic, the utilization of perovskite-based oxides enables the design of metallic nanoparticles. Indeed, exsolution stands out as a novel technique in crafting stable catalysts [124] since the strong interfacial adhesion of nanoparticles to the surface improves the stability by preventing agglomeration and reducing susceptibility to coke formation [125]. More recently, many perovskite-derived medium-entropy alloys (MEAs) or high-entropy alloys (HEAs) have been reported employing the emerging exsolution method (Table 5) [44,71,75,97,101,107,110–112,121,123,126–131]. As expected for increased configurational entropy materials, the design of perovskite-derived MEAs or HEAs can exhibit synergistic effects, enhancing CH4 activation or demonstrating superior long-term performance compared to the perovskite precursor or its analogous low-entropy nanoparticles. As evidence of these advantages and to validate significant trends, Shah and colleagues [125] designed NiFeCo nanoparticles derived from multielemental La(Fe,Ni,Co)O3 perovskite precursors by the exsolution technique, aiming to control size, composition, and reactivity (Fig. 11 a). In fact, this study underscores that partially substituting Fe with Ni and Co modifies the reducibility of the precursor, exsolution kinetics, and catalyst nanoparticle performance. In more detail, the study observed that reducing the temperature influences the nanoparticle characteristics: NiFeCo nanoparticles at 800 °C were initially smaller than those at 950 °C. However, over time, in dry reforming of the methane reaction environment, the activity of the 800 °C system decreased to match the activity profile of the 950 °C materials. Initially, Fe-rich nanoparticles were obtained (Fig. 11b) through reduction at a greater temperature, but after aging for 24 h, they became Ni- and Co-rich in the reactive atmosphere, as confirmed by high-angle annular dark-field-scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM). Among the various compositions tested, the catalyst with improved performance was characterized by presenting elevated Ni content and a higher concentration of oxygen vacancies that promote CO2 and CH4 activation. This study offers insights into key factors governing properties and clarifies the relationship between crystalline structure and reactivity of multimetallic nanoparticles derived from perovskite oxide precursors. Shah et al. [107] also used exsolution-mediated synthesis for the formation of nanoparticles from HEP oxide precursors (LaFe0.7Ni0.1Co0.1Cu0.05Pd0.05O3) (Fig. 11c). Fascinatingly, shorter reduction times or lower reduction temperatures (700 °C) encourage a single-phase metallic configuration with all five metals, which characterizes a HEM. Conversely, elevated reduction temperatures (900 °C) combined with prolonged reduction times foster a phase-separated heterostructure characterized by two distinct domains (Fig. 11d). In this scenario, Cu and Pd exhibit a tendency to co-localize, while Ni, Fe, and Co tend to integrate into a solid solution within the nanoparticle. As the reduction temperature rises, the nanoparticles tend to become richer in Fe content, aligning with earlier observations highlighting predominant Fe exsolution at higher temperatures. Moreover, bulk exsolution demonstrates a trend wherein nanoparticles can transition from a HEA to a phase-separated heterostructure at elevated reduction temperatures. Consistent with observations in high-entropy systems and various multi-element materials, the NiFeCoCuPd nanoparticles exhibited sustained activity, attributed to the stabilizing interaction among the diverse metals, whether in a single-phase or heterostructure configuration. The NiFeCoCuPd-700 reaction outperforms NiFeCoCuPd-900, activating CH4 more efficiently at ∼570 °C versus 695 °C (Fig. 11e, f), likely due to a smaller nanoparticle size and a higher concentration of active components synergistic interaction of Ni with Pd and Cu. NiFeCoCuPd-700 initially produces CO-rich syngas at lower temperatures, transitioning to H2-rich at higher temperatures, while NiFeCoCuPd-900 consistently forms CO-rich syngas across all temperatures. These distinctions underscore how composition variations from reduction temperature alterations can impact both activity and selectivity in the reaction. Lately, there has been an interest in Heusler alloys, an intermetallic alloy with the general X2YZ structure, as a catalyst for methanol steam reforming [109]. These materials may lead to a synergetic effect between the ternary compound, depending on the X-Y-Z elements selected as described in Fig. 12 (a, b), with multiple organization patterns as shown in Fig. 12(c), depending on the desired properties of the catalyst. According to Kojima et al. [132], the main activity of the catalyst is delivered by X elements, while Y and Z can improve the activity, selectivity, and durability of the medium and high entropy catalysts. The hydrogen production rate over MEA Co2TiAl and Ni2TiAl was significantly superior when compared to Co2FeGa, Co2FeGe, and Co2MnGe due to fine particle formation led by Ti selective oxidation. In addition, notable research in the literature explores the steam reforming of HEAs.
