However, the existing studies are primarily focused on the reforming of biomass tar [133], toluene [134], and methane [135]. Consequently, there is a lack of publications specifically addressing the use of HEAs in ethanol steam reforming. This gap highlights a promising area for further investigation, particularly if preliminary studies demonstrate favorable catalytic performance. Shah et al. [107] further advanced this approach by employing LaFe0.70Ni0.10Co0.10Cu0.05Pd0.05O3 perovskite oxide precursors to synthesize NiFeCoCuPd nanoparticles via exsolution. The resulting catalysts displayed distinct structural and catalytic behaviors depending on the reduction temperature and dwell time. Reduction at 700 °C yielded smaller (∼12 nm), homogeneously distributed complex concentrated alloy nanoparticles, while reduction at 900 °C produced larger (∼29 nm) phase-separated heterostructures, with Ni-Fe-Co forming a solid solution and Pd-Cu domains segregating. The smaller NiFeCoCuPd-700 catalyst achieved superior DMR activity, reaching CH4 and CO2 conversions of ∼68 % and ∼64 %, respectively, at 700 °C, and maintained a stable H2/CO ratio of ∼0.8 over 24 h on stream. In contrast, the NiFeCoCuPd-900 catalyst showed lower conversions (∼42 % CH4, ∼38 % CO2) and a lower H2/CO ratio (∼0.6), attributed to sintering and diminished surface area. High-resolution STEM and XPS analyses revealed that the exsolved nanoparticles were strongly anchored to a periclase-type La2O3-LaFeO3 matrix, which provided thermal stability and enhanced oxygen mobility. The optimized thermal treatment and controlled exsolution enabled the formation of highly dispersed active sites with minimal coke formation (0.06 mg/100 mg catalyst for NiFeCoCuPd-700 versus 1.45 mg for NiFeCoCuPd-900). These findings emphasize how periclase-derived supports, combined with entropy-driven stabilization and tailored reduction strategies, facilitate the synthesis of robust multimetallic catalysts with exceptional activity, selectivity, and long-term stability in CH4 reforming environments. Notably, nearly all of these materials are metal oxides depicted in Table 6, with the most exhibiting conversion efficiencies equal to or exceeding 99 % [28,81,83,84,102–106,109,116–120,122,136–140]. This performance is particularly remarkable when contrasted with the relatively lower conversion rates typically reported for high- and medium-entropy materials applied in CH4 reforming (Table 5). Moreover, the data indicate that such high conversion values are consistently achieved at temperatures below 700 °C, an uncommon condition for syngas production, underscoring the growing strategic relevance of MEM and HEM catalysts in reforming applications. Strikingly, several systems demonstrated complete conversion at temperatures below 500 °C and, in some cases, even below 400 °C. Among these, catalysts derived from hydrotalcite-type precursors, discussed in Section 4.2, deserve particular attention. These materials, positively charged brucite-like layered double hydroxides (LDHs), undergo thermal decomposition to yield thermally stable mixed oxides with high surface areas and homogeneous active sites. These structural and textural attributes are critical in enabling outstanding catalytic performance in the 250–350 °C temperature range. 5 Statistical analysis A multivariate descriptive analysis was conducted to evaluate the formulations reported in the literature, considering factors such as elemental composition, reforming temperature, H2/CO ratio, synthesis methods, most frequently studied crystal structures, and normalized values of H2/CO ratio, fuel conversion, and gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) for the materials listed in Tables 5 and 6. 5.1 Statistical analysis for the catalyst formulations in methane reforming According to Table 5, 46 distinct formulations have been investigated, with several studies examining the reforming process under varying conditions, including temperature variations [123,130,132] and element proportion [74,97,110,111]. Fig. 13 (a) illustrates the overall elemental composition across all compiled formulations, while Fig. 13(b) presents the frequency of studies investigating each element. Nickel (Ni) emerges as the most widely employed element for methane reforming, appearing in 94 % of the analyzed works. This prevalence stems from Ni’s early adoption in this field, owing to its low cost, favorable catalytic properties, high hydrogen selectivity, efficient C–H bond activation, and substantial fuel conversion efficiency [141–143]. The major problems of Ni catalysts are the metal sintering by the coarsening mechanism and rapid deactivation by carbon deposition on the surface, which leads to low stability of the material and is not interesting for industrial processes [144,145]. In fact, the main catalysts reported in the literature for methane reforming are Ni-based and noble metal-based catalysts [145,146]. Noble metal-based catalysts exhibit higher stability and reduced coke formation. However, recent studies have shifted focus to non-noble metal-containing catalysts due to the scarcity and high cost of noble metals [44]. An effective strategy to address this challenge involves incorporating elements with enhanced coke resistance and stability into Ni-based systems. In this context, the ME- and HEMs emerge as a great alternative to integrate different elements. The incorporation of metal species with strong alkalinity, such as Al, Mg, and La, improves the catalyst stability and promotes the chemisorption, CO2 dissociation, and gasification of amorphous carbon, improving the system’s coke resistance [44,147]. The main elements explored in the selected works and compositions, respectively, are Ni (94.1 % and 84.7 %), Co (64.7 % and 58.7 %), Fe (47 % and 43.4 %), and La (35.2 % and 41.3 %), as seen in Fig. 13(a and b). Cobalt plays a crucial role in reforming processes due to its intrinsic properties of high oxygen affinity and great fuel conversion. Furthermore, Co and Ni share similar atomic radii, chemical affinities, and properties, making it easier to synthesize alloys or metal oxides with different element incorporation [148]. Lanthanum has also emerged as a promising alternative, mainly for perovskite oxides, playing a structural role within the unit cell. Additionally, lanthanum is a key element for improving stability, reducing catalyst deactivation, helping with elementary dispersion for ME- and HEMs, and producing smaller crystallite sizes [149,150]. Other elements such as Fe, Ba, and Ce have been widely explored in this area because of the high dispersion and lattice distortion, and excellent properties for ME- and HEMs [151]. Thus, these elements exhibit great reforming performance and CH4 selectivity because they act as oxygen carriers [44,97,129,130]. For instance, the Co x Ni0.80− x La0.20Ca0.50Ce0.50@Al2O3 HEM catalyst demonstrated outstanding performance in DRM, achieving up to 99.36 % CH4 conversion and a H2 yield of 539.3 mmol/gcat/h at 850 °C. These results surpass those of conventional Ni-based systems and are closely tied to the catalyst’s unique structure and morphology. SEM and TEM analyses revealed an LDH precursor that transformed into a highly dispersed solid solution phase with FCC symmetry upon reduction, as evidenced by XRD. This FCC structure, with nanosheets (∼895.7 nm) and finely dispersed crystallites (∼193.9 nm) on the porous Al2O3 support, provides abundant active sites and promotes superior anti-sintering properties. This configuration delivers a high specific surface area (88.4 m2/g) and substantial pore volume (0.37 cm3/g), enhancing reactant adsorption and activation. Furthermore, the uniform distribution of Co, Ni, La, Ca, and Ce observed via EDS mapping indicates strong alloying effects that promote lattice distortion and oxygen vacancy formation, critical for carbon removal during reaction cycles. As a result, the catalyst maintained stable activity over 12 h of continuous operation at 650 °C, with minimal sintering or coke formation. Notably, the system sustained an H2/CO ratio near 0.9 across 500–650 °C, reflecting effective thermodynamic regulation and offering advantages for downstream synthesis by reducing separation energy requirements [126]. The CoFeGaNiZn/CeO2 HEA hybrid catalyst also exhibits an FCC solid solution structure, as confirmed by XRD patterns showing characteristic peaks from CeO2 and evidence of highly dispersed HEA phases undetectable by XRD due to their nanoscale distribution [131]. Electron microscopy analyses reveal that the HEA nanoparticles are uniformly dispersed and anchored on CeO2 surfaces, forming sharp and stable interfaces without voids or cracks even after 30 h of DRM operation at 750 °C. The optimized 7 wt % CoFeGaNiZn/CeO2 catalyst achieved exceptional performance, with CH4 and CO2 conversions of 99.9 % and 87.9 %, respectively, at 750 °C, and sustained 98.6 % CH4 and 86.4 % CO2 conversion after 30 h of continuous operation. The catalyst also maintained an H2/CO ratio of 1.29, indicating efficient DRM reaction pathways and minimal side reactions. This remarkable activity and stability are attributed to the unique combination of the FCC HEA phase and CeO2 support, which provides high oxygen storage capacity and facilitates lattice oxygen participation in methane partial oxidation, as confirmed by DFT calculations and transient studies [131]. The superior performance of this hybrid system underscores the critical role of the modified sol-gel synthesis method, which promotes homogeneous dispersion of HEA nanoparticles and tough contact with the CeO2 support. The thermal treatments, including annealing at 1100 °C and calcination at 400 °C, enhance crystallinity and ensure the formation of a robust FCC phase while preserving surface oxygen vacancies crucial for CO2 activation. The strong metal-support interactions and the nanoscale architecture of HEA particles mitigate sintering and coke deposition, ensuring long-term catalytic stability. Additionally, the fine dispersion of HEA on the mesoporous CeO2 support increases active site accessibility and optimizes the balance between metallic and oxidized species, which is vital for redox cycles during DRM. Overall, the synthesis strategy, processing steps, structural features, and engineered catalyst-support synergy collectively dictate the outstanding activity, selectivity, and durability of this system under harsh reforming conditions [131]. Regarding the material structures for reforming applications, the perovskite phase is the most explored as ME- and HEM (Fig. 14 a), representing 43.4 % of the total structures reported. In fact, perovskite is a great alternative because the architecture makes it possible to create anodic vacancies that work as oxygen carriers, improving the methane reforming process. Extensive works were found in the literature studying the perovskites specifically for chemical looping reforming reactions, and in this field, dry and steam reforming systems have been explored [97,152,153]. Especially for perovskite and spinel structures, a tendency to design materials with potential ex-solution metallic phases was found from the B site. From the explored works, the exsolved phases were Fe-Ni-Co [128,129], Fe-Ni [112], Ni-Co [101], Ni [110], and Ni-Mo-Co [127]. An analysis of the most employed synthesis methods reveals that sol-gel and coprecipitation techniques are widely utilized due to their simplicity and well-established protocols, which do not require complex equipment or procedures to produce the desired materials. Moreover, these methods allow for precise control over stoichiometry, enabling the preparation of diverse structures, an important advantage for the synthesis of medium- and high-entropy materials. It was found that nearly 80 % of the catalysts reported in the literature were synthesized using sol-gel and coprecipitation routes, as illustrated in Fig. 14(b). The hydrothermal method, therefore, has been explored in only 7.14 % of the total formulations presented in Table 5. Although this method is widely employed to obtain controlled nanostructures, its operational risks make it less suitable for industrial processes, which explains the limited exploration of this technique. Another important parameter to consider is the process temperature, which varies depending on the type of reforming and the reactor configuration employed in each study. As shown in Fig. 14(c), most experiments were conducted at temperatures above 800 °C, with 47.8 % of the total experiments performed at 800 °C and 19.5 % at 900 °C. Temperature plays a critical role in industrial processes, as higher temperatures generally enhance conversion rates and selectivity. However, despite the improved performance at elevated temperatures, such conditions can also lead to increased operational costs and promote catalyst sintering, ultimately resulting in catalyst deactivation [49,123]. Recently, some materials have been developed focusing on the anti-sintering properties during methane reforming [44]. As discussed in the previous section, dry reforming of methane (DRM) offers distinct advantages over other reforming pathways, such as utilizing CO2 as a reactant and operating under conditions favorable for syngas production with lower H2/CO ratios. It is also interesting to notice that most experiments were carried out in the dry reforming setup, showing the global efforts to engineer new materials for low-carbon step processes, to develop energy solutions. The GHSV is also a great parameter to evaluate, as it expresses the interaction time between the catalyst and the gases. Low values of GHSV might suggest two different interpretations: dilution of the reactant gas with an inert gas or incomplete interaction of the gases with the catalyst surface, which may lead to low conversion values because the reactant’s adsorption is not sufficient to complete the methane conversion. Accordingly, high values of this parameter are considered beneficial for catalytic processes [154]. This relation can be seen in Fig. 15 , and most of the reforming processes herein analyzed employ GHSV equal to or higher than 30000 mL/gcat/h for a complete catalyst-gas interaction. As shown in Fig. 15, the conversion has an intrinsic relation to the composition and the elements present in the ME- and HEM, as the different elements have different catalytic performances and directly affect the CH4 conversion [123,129,130]. In the La1− x Sr x Ni0.8Zr0.2O3 catalyst series, optimizing the La/Sr ratio led to a remarkable enhancement in catalytic performance: methane conversion increased from 15 % for La0.2Sr0.8Ni0.8Zr0.2O3 to 90 % for La0.8Sr0.2Ni0.8Zr0.2O3 at 800 °C [111]. This improvement highlights the beneficial role of La3+ incorporation in promoting catalytic activity, likely due to enhanced oxygen mobility and defect formation within the perovskite lattice. Another point is the composition selection to design a new catalyst, since the most used elements exhibited good values of conversion. In fact, 88 % of the formulations that exhibit a CH4 conversion rate equal to or higher than 75 % contain at least three elements of the following: Ni, Co, Mg, Al, La, and Fe. In the catalyst, Ni and Co serve as the primary redox-active centers, facilitating methane activation and hydrogen evolution through their variable oxidation states. Mg and Al contribute structural stability and thermal resistance, suppressing sintering and maintaining high surface area. La3+ promotes oxygen mobility and introduces oxygen vacancies via charge compensation, which supports coke oxidation and enhances lattice oxygen participation. Fe, with its multivalent nature, further enriches redox cycling and aids in regenerating active sites. The interplay among these elements generates a chemically disordered but structurally coherent matrix, enabling emergent properties, such as enhanced defect chemistry, cooperative adsorption, and multi-site activation mechanisms, that are not achievable in conventional single- or binary-metal systems. Finally, the H2/CO ratio depends on specific factors of syngas production interests and is strongly variable, as seen in Fig. 15 for analyzing the reaction parameters. Considering different formulations in a particular work varying the stoichiometry of the developed material, the ratio tends to remain within a low variation range, as follows in the explored works [97,101,123]. An H2/CO ratio greater than 1 indicates that the reforming process produces more hydrogen than CO, which is desirable in SRM, while ratio values lower than 1 are not very interesting because of the coke deposition. In overall consideration, 54.3 % of ratios reported are higher than one, which is good for the applications focused on hydrogen-rich syngas, such as pure hydrogen and ammonia production. On the other hand, the shift toward a lower H2/CO ratio brings the product gas closer to the stoichiometric target of 1:1, desirable in DRM applications, favoring CO2 utilization and syngas balance. For example, substituting a small amount of Al3+ with La3+ in the catalyst Ni2Mg4Al2O x results in a notable performance shift: the La-modified composition Ni2Mg4Al1.8La0.2O x achieves a more favorable H2/CO ratio of 1.1 compared to 2.5 for the unmodified system, while maintaining a high CH4 conversion of approximately 90 %. This suggests that La3+ incorporation effectively enhances the stoichiometric balance of the DRM reaction (1):1 H2:CO) and contributes to reduced coke formation due to improved oxygen mobility and defect engineering [123]. 5.2 Statistical analysis for the catalyst formulations in ethanol and methanol reforming As shown in Table 6, 43 different formulations were explored for ethanol/methanol reforming, and nickel showed up as the main active phase in 58.1 % of the formulations studied, followed by aluminium (48.8 %), lanthanum (44.2 %), cobalt (32.5 %), and copper (30.2 %). The tendency to use Ni, Co, and La is a majority for both methane and ethanol/methanol reforming, and Cu is mostly used as a composition element for ethanol/methanol reforming in HEMs and MEMs. It comes from the fact that Cu is a well-established catalyst in the hydrogenation field to produce alcohols [155,156]. The elements used in all considered compositions are represented in Fig. 16 (a, b). From the transition metals to rare earth elements, there is no significant variance in elements employed for methane and ethanol/methanol catalysts, which is highly indicative that if the catalyst is successfully employed in methane reforming, it might also work for ethanol/methanol reforming, as well as the opposite. Regarding the structures explored in catalysts used for alcohol reforming, as exhibited in Fig. 17 (a), the perovskite phase is the most extensively synthesized, representing 51.1 % of the total formulations analyzed in this work. Spinel structure is also well explored in ethanol/methanol reforming, accounting for 27.9 %, while periclase represents 16.2 % of the formulations. It is also noteworthy that layered double hydroxides (LDHs) containing a hydrotalcite-like structure are widely used as precursors, with the number of works using the double-layer precursor strategy representing 30.2 % of the total, which may indicate a growing strategy to develop catalysts for this area. The hydrotalcite-like structure is interesting for HEMs and MEMs development, once the mobility of cations during the hydrotalcite decomposition represents a thermodynamically favoured entropy design. Fig. 17(b) shows that the synthesis routes most explored are also sol-gel (39.5 %) and coprecipitation (41.8 %), as well as for methane reforming catalysts. It was also noticed that most of the LDH precursors are obtained from the coprecipitation method. Not only is arc-melting a process explored to obtain high-purity metal ingots, which comes from metallurgy and consists of metals/alloys melting from a high-temperature arc between two electrodes, but it has also been the most explored route to obtain HEAs [157]. In terms of temperature for alcohol reforming, as illustrated in Fig. 17(c), most experiments are conducted at 500 °C (18.6 % of total). For ethanol/methanol reforming, the process temperature is considerably lower compared to methane reforming, which comes from the reactivity contribution of OH– groups in alcohols, the lower energy required to break the C–O bonds compared to C–H in methane, and chemical and compositional factors that lead to a higher reactivity of alcohol molecules. Additionally, the temperature employed in alcohol reforming is broader than that used for methane in the analyzed studies (ΔT = 550 °C for alcohols and ΔT = 350 °C for methane). Furthermore, the WHSV exhibits considerably greater variability in alcohol reforming compared to methane reforming, as illustrated in Fig. 18 . This variation can be attributed to the prevalent use of the SR process in many studies listed in Table 6 (alcohol reforming), where WHSV is influenced by species dilution during reforming. Another important aspect of alcohol reforming is the total fuel conversion, as alcohol molecules decompose into smaller carbon-containing species such as acetaldehyde (CH3CHO), methane (CH4), carbon monoxide (CO), and carbon dioxide (CO2), which are commonly reported byproducts. According to Table 6, 60.4 % of the formulations analyzed achieve complete conversion of alcohols, both ethanol and methanol, demonstrating excellent catalytic performance, as can be seen to the catalysts Mg0.5Al0.25Ni0.25O x , Mg0.46Ni0.69Zn1.85AlO x , La0.6Sr0.4Co0.8Fe0.2O3− δ , La0.7Ca0.3Fe0.7Co0.3O3, Co0.22Ti0.46Al0.31, La0.8Ce0.2Mn0.6Ni0.4O3, La0.4Ca0.4Ni0.03Ti0.97O3− δ and their different stoichiometry variations. It is also evident from Fig. 18 that the H2/CO ratio is substantially higher for alcohol reforming than for methane reforming, although the formation of byproducts is often disregarded due to incomplete quantification in the literature. Finally, the best performance catalysts for alcohol reforming are exhibited in Fig. 18 in terms of WHSV, conversion, and H2/CO ratio for different temperatures, and most of the highly active catalysts operate in temperatures lower than 650 °C, corroborating the data shown and discussed in Fig. 17(c). From a compositional point of view, from the 20 best performance catalysts, 60 % employed Ni in formulation, 50 % used La, 40 % used Co, and 35 % used Al, corresponding to an effective analysis of the most used elements for HEMs and MEM catalysts design. 6 Conclusions and outlook The advancement of new materials stands as a key strategy in propelling promising avenues for energy conversion and storage during the ongoing energy transition. Recent strides in crafting medium- and high-entropy materials (MEMs and HEMs) have unveiled substantial progress in critical realms vital for decarbonization. Notably, these materials have shown significant promise in catalyzing the generation of hydrogen from the reforming of strategic fuels like methane, biogas, ethanol, methanol, and more. Recent advancements in hydrogen production through methane, biogas, and natural gas catalytic reforming underscore the prevalence of Ni-containing medium- and high-entropy systems as catalysts. Notably, elements like Al, Mg, Co, La, and Fe have also been highlighted, despite some being utilized in more specific phases like Ba and Sr into medium- and high-entropy perovskite. The ethanol and methanol reforming landscape has highlighted five key elements: Ni, Al, La, Co, and Cu. Unlike methane reforming catalysts, where Fe plays a significant role, the substitution with Cu in ethanol steam reforming is attributed to its ability to promote the water-gas shift reaction (WGSR). In addition to composition, structural characteristics play a crucial role in catalysis. These properties can be precisely tailored in various metal oxide phases, such as perovskite, periclase, and spinel structures, particularly by increasing the configurational entropy of the system. Within the realm of medium- and high-entropy oxides (MEOs and HEOs), several synthesis methodologies have gained widespread attention. Notably, recent advancements emphasize the potential of medium- to high-entropy layered double hydroxides (ME-LDHs/HE-LDHs) as precursors for a wide range of MEOs and HEOs, especially in catalysts based on spinel and periclase-type oxide structures. Conversely, emerging exsolution techniques have enabled the development of medium-entropy alloys (MEAs) and high-entropy alloys (HEAs) derived from perovskite structures. These materials, with their heightened configurational entropy, exhibit synergistic effects that enhance CH4 activation and demonstrate superior long-term stability compared to their perovskite precursors or low-entropy counterparts. Perovskites have become a focal point in ethanol steam reforming due to their exceptional oxygen transport capabilities, which significantly enhance catalytic activity and inhibit coke formation. This structural advantage positions perovskites as a foundational material for catalyst design. Looking ahead, the development of ME- and HEMs based on perovskite structures holds great promise. While substantial strides have been made in recent years towards designing MEMs and/or HEMs as catalysts for hydrogen production via renewable fuel reforming, this field remains in its infancy. Challenges and hurdles persist, impeding mass production, compositional control, structural characterization, commercialization, and the unlocking of their complete potential for practical applications in this emerging domain. For instance, achieving homogeneous distribution of multiple elements at the nanoscale is intrinsically complex, owing to disparities in atomic size, electronegativity, and bonding tendencies among constituent elements. These differences often lead to issues with phase segregation, poor reproducibility, and limited scalability. Moreover, many of the current synthetic strategies are based on multi-step, time- and energy-intensive procedures that are not readily translatable to industrial-scale production. From a characterization standpoint, the stochastic nature of elemental distribution complicates the identification of catalytically active sites and hampers the elucidation of structure-activity relationships. This, in turn, limits the ability to rationally optimize catalytic performance in terms of activity, selectivity, and stability. Compounding these challenges is the absence of robust design principles to guide the selection of elemental combinations and compositional ratios tailored to specific catalytic processes. In the context of catalytic reforming of strategic renewable fuels, ensuring the formation and retention of single-phase solid solutions, while suppressing phase separation or surface segregation, remains particularly difficult, especially under the thermally harsh conditions typically encountered during operation. To surmount these significant constraints, future perspectives and directions should be contemplated. These are summarized in Scheme 2 and highlighted below for consideration in addressing the existing challenges and paving the way forward. (1) The advancement of MEMs and HEMs demands considerable development in the upcoming years, striving for more straightforward, expedited, and scalable synthetic pathways. Envisioning the future, there lies the potential for diverse MEMs and HEMs, including MXenes, carbides, MOF-derived materials, Prussian blue analogues (PBAs) derived materials, and other coordination compounds-derived variants as emerging catalytic materials. (2) Beyond the design of novel ME- and HEM-based materials and coordination compound derivatives, the accurate classification of materials as low-, medium-, or high-entropy systems based on calculated configurational entropy is essential to prevent misinterpretations and the dissemination of conceptual inaccuracies. Moreover, the use of elemental analysis techniques, such as inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectrometry (ICP-OES) and flame atomic absorption spectrometry (FAAS), is critical for determining the actual metal content in the final compositions. This is particularly important given that many studies still rely solely on the precursor salt ratios to estimate configurational entropy, which can lead to misleading conclusions. In addition, peer review processes should adopt a more rigorous stance regarding the classification of entropy levels, particularly through expert assessment and the recommendation of targeted experiments. This approach is essential to minimize errors and prevent the spread of misconceptions, especially when such inaccuracies can be easily avoided through proper validation. (3) Catalyst resistance to H2S poisoning and coke deactivation requires further optimization for field applications. The incorporation of elements such as molybdenum, niobium, tantalum, and tungsten can enhance H2S resistance by enabling a mechanism involving M−S oxidation. Additionally, while exsolution strategies have demonstrated effectiveness in mitigating coke formation, further studies are needed to optimize the chemical composition of the parent-exsolved interface, enhancing its protective properties and performance of MEM and HEM catalysts. (4) While medium- and high-entropy catalysts exist, numerous reforming catalysts undergo structural and morphological alterations at high temperatures during catalytic processes. To comprehensively grasp catalyst mechanisms, exsolution process, and/or degradation to propose enhanced alternatives, in-depth investigations utilizing in situ and operando methods are imperative. These methods provide real-time insights into intermediates, reaction mechanisms, and the intricate relationships between structure and reactivity, facilitating the development of more efficient catalysts. Sophisticated in-situ and operando spectroscopy techniques utilizing synchrotron light are pivotal among these methods. Moreover, the foreseeable use of in-situ transmission electron microscopy techniques, particularly in gas environmental cells with controlled heating, holds promise for uncovering valuable insights in the development of novel and MEOs and HEOs or alloys derived from metal hydroxides or perovskites, respectively. (5) Harnessing artificial intelligence AI for the rational design and optimization of medium- and high-entropy materials demands the integration of diverse, high-quality datasets derived from both experimental and computational sources. The construction of predictive models can be greatly enhanced by combining ab initio data (e.g., DFT-calculated adsorption energies, formation enthalpies) with experimental metrics such as catalytic activity, thermal stability, and deactivation rates under realistic reforming conditions. Strategies such as active learning, Bayesian optimization, and transfer learning can iteratively guide experiments toward the most promising compositions, reducing the number of costly and time-consuming synthesis trials. In particular, graph-based deep learning architectures (e.g., CGCNN, MEGNet) enable direct mapping of atomic environments to target properties without the need for handcrafted descriptors. Future research should prioritize the development of standardized, open-access databases for HEM catalysts under relevant operating conditions, which will serve as a critical foundation for robust, generalizable models. Such data-driven approaches are poised to revolutionize the discovery pipeline for hydrogen-generation catalysts by enabling rapid, interpretable, and cost-effective exploration of an immense compositional design space. (6) To enable the widespread adoption of hydrogen production from renewable fuels such as ethanol, methanol, or biomethane, it is critical to address both capital and operational expenditures that dominate the levelized cost of hydrogen (LCOH). High- and medium-entropy catalysts (HECs and MECs) offer a promising pathway to lower LCOH by enabling efficient catalytic reforming at intermediate temperatures (<400 °C), which significantly reduces energy demands and eliminates the need for expensive reactor materials like Inconel®. This thermal advantage facilitates the use of more economical stainless-steel alloys, thus reducing CAPEX and supporting the development of modular, decentralized hydrogen generation systems. Furthermore, the catalyst formulation should be strategically optimized for cost-effectiveness. Future material designs should prioritize compositions with cobalt-low or cobalt-less formulations and avoid the use of noble metals whenever possible. Fortunately, nickel does not currently pose a significant risk in terms of supply constraints [158], which is advantageous given its widespread use in the development of medium- and high-entropy-based catalysts. Within this context, compositions enriched in Ni, Fe, Mn, and Cu warrant further exploration due to their potential cost benefits, while Co may be employed in small amounts as a dopant to improve catalytic performance. Future research should prioritize holistic LCOH assessments that incorporate the broader impacts of catalyst composition, operating conditions, and plant design, recognizing that the intrinsic stability and tunability of entropy-stabilized materials may unlock transformative cost reductions in the hydrogen economy. In summary, the recent progress in employing MEMs and HEMs for hydrogen production through renewable fuel reforming represents promising strides. However, substantial efforts are still required to fulfill the requirements of our energy-intensive society. Sofia Baúti holds a bachelor’s degree in Materials Engineering from the Federal University of Lavras (UFLA, 2022) and a master’s degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of Campinas (UNICAMP, 2025). She has research experience in the development of electrocatalysts for water splitting, acquired during her internship at LNNano – CNPEM (2022), and in high-entropy catalysts for heterogeneous catalysis in methane reforming, with a focus on the spray-drying technique. She is currently a member of the Extreme Conditions Laboratory (LCTE) at the Brazilian Synchrotron Light Laboratory (LNLS, CNPEM), where she supports national and international users in sample preparation for synchrotron experiments. João Victor T. Feyhis a doctoral researcher at the Advanced Energy Storage Division of the Center for Innovation on New Energies, Brazil. He obtained his bachelor’s degree in chemical engineering from the State University of Santa Catarina (UDESC) and his MsC from the School of Chemical Engineering at the State University of Campinas (UNICAMP) in 2025. He worked on the development of two catalytic reforming systems (DRM/SRM and SRE), and also on the synthesis of catalysts via spray dryer technology. Fábio Coutinho Antunesis a Ph.D. in materials science and engineering at UFSCar. Has experience in the manufacturing of solid oxide fuel cells (SOFCs), and electrochemical, structural, and microstructural characterization of composite electrolytes and electrodes for application in SOFCs. Also has experience in the manufacturing of SOFC components by tape casting, screen printing, and airbrushing of metallic and ceramic slurries, besides spin and dip coating of sol gels and colloidal suspensions. He is currently a post-doctoral student in the advanced energy storage (AES) division of the Center for Innovation in New Energies (CINE) at CEPETRO/UNICAMP, developing metal-supported SOFCs (MS-SOFCs) for biofuels on-board electrical generation in hybrid electric vehicles and stationary and decentralized power generation from biomethane reformed from refined biogas. Thiago Diasis a post-doctoral researcher at the Advanced Energy Storage Division of the Center for Innovation on New Energies in Campinas, Brazil. He obtained his bachelor’s degree in physics from the Federal University of São Carlos in 2002, followed by a Master's (2005) and a PhD (2009) degree in Materials Engineering from the same university, specializing in materials for solid oxide fuel cells (SOFC). His research interests extend to biomaterials, varistors, supercapacitors, and the comprehensive study of SOFCs, ranging from material development to device operation using fuels such as hydrogen, bioethanol, and biomethane. Gustavo Doubek holds a degree in Chemical Engineering from the University of Campinas - UNICAMP and a PhD in Nuclear Technology - Materials from the Institute of Nuclear and Energy Research - IPEN/USP, having worked as a visiting researcher at YALE University - USA and as a product developer at 3M in the R&D&I area. He is currently an Associate Professor at the University of Campinas and a researcher at the Center for Innovation in New Energies - CINE in the Advanced Energy Storage division. He has experience in the design and synthesis of nanomaterials applied to energy conversion and storage devices and product innovation processes. He works mainly on the following topics: Development of intercalation batteries such as Li-Ion, Na-ion, conversion Batteries such as Li-O2 and Li-S, and Fuel Cells for energy storage and conversion, Biofuel reformers, and synthesis of catalysts and functional materials with several projects both with public and private funding. Josué M. Gonçalves is a Researcher at the Mackenzie Institute for Research in Graphene and Nanotechnologies (MackGraphe) within the Mackenzie Presbyterian Institute, Brazil. He graduated in Chemistry at the University Vale do Acaraú (UVA) in 2014 and received his PhD from the Institute of Chemistry at the University of São Paulo (USP) in 2019. He developed cutting-edge research during his postdoctoral internships at USP (2019–2021), the University of Illinois-Chicago (UIC, 2021–2022), and the University of Campinas (Unicamp, 2023–2024). His current research interests include applications of high-entropy materials for sensors, electrocatalysis, energy conversion, and storage devices. Bruno B.N.S. Brandão is a post-doctoral researcher at the Advanced Energy Storage Division of the Center for Innovation on New Energies, Brazil. He obtained his bachelor’s degree in chemistry from the Federal University of Minas Gerais and his PhD from the Institute of Chemistry at the University of São Paulo (USP) in 2021. He worked on synthesizing magneto-fluorescent materials, leading an open-innovation project with USP and Metal Chek company. He currently develops high-entropy and nano-microstructured materials via spray dryer technology for catalytic reforming of ethanol and biomethane, batteries cathodes, and SOFC anodes, focusing on scalonable processes. Hudson Zanin is a Professor at the School of Electrical and Computer Engineering of the University of Campinas, Brazil, and a Researcher in the Advanced Energy Storage Division of the Center for Innovation on New Energies. His research focuses on developing functional (nano)materials and their application in Energy Storage and Conversion Devices. He has experience in supercapacitors, batteries, and fuel cells’ materials and devices. He is the founder of the first South American lab-scale batteries and supercapacitors manufacturing. Dr. Zanin has a Ph.D. degree in Electrical Engineering from the University of Campinas (2012).

coredata.dc:description: Hydrogen production via catalytic reforming of renewable fuels represents a pivotal strategy in the decarbonization of energy systems. However, conventional catalysts continue to encounter persistent challenges, including sintering, carbon deposition, and structural degradation under severe reaction conditions. This review addresses the growing need to consolidate the rapidly expanding body of knowledge on medium- and high-entropy materials (MEMs and HEMs), whose unique thermodynamic features position them as next-generation catalysts with the potential to overcome these limitations. The discussion is organized to examine how entropy stabilization, lattice distortion, and multi-elemental synergy influence catalytic behavior. Materials are categorized by crystal structure (e.g., perovskite, spinel, and periclase) and by their roles in key reforming processes, including steam, dry, partial oxidation, and autothermal reforming of renewable fuels such as bioethanol, biomethane, and methanol. A detailed comparison of synthesis methods, configurational entropy thresholds, and physicochemical characteristics is presented. The review synthesizes key insights from recent studies, including advances in exsolution-driven nanostructuring, the impact of oxygen vacancy engineering, and the performance of entropy-optimized compositions under practical reforming conditions. It offers a comprehensive mapping of structure-performance relationships, underscoring how entropy can be harnessed to design more robust, selective, and efficient catalytic systems. Future perspectives emphasize the exploration of underinvestigated entropy-stabilized systems (e.g., nitrides and sulfides), the integration of data-driven design approaches, and the imperative for long-term stability evaluations under industrially relevant conditions. Finally, the review highlights promising opportunities for scaling up entropy-based catalysts and aligning their development with techno-economic and environmental benchmarks. This work aims to serve as both a comprehensive reference and a strategic outlook for advancing hydrogen production technologies through entropy-engineered catalysis.
